B. The business license fee for such operation shall be pursuant to subsection 3-1-5D of this title. (Ord.
2017-O-038, 11-13-2017)
Chapter 17
SPECIAL EVENTS
3-17-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
Any special events on public ways or public property controlled by the Village shall be allowed by permit
only. (Ord. 2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 175/714
3-17-2: SPECIAL EVENTS DEFINED:
"Special events" as used in this chapter shall mean group events or events to which the general public is
invited as either a participant or a spectator and shall include, but not be limited to, parades, special
occasion photography on Village property, picnics on public property, festivals, athletic competitions or
events and other similar events or activities on Village owned property or utilizing Village resources. (Ord.
2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
3-17-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
An application to conduct a special event shall be made in writing to the Village pursuant to the Special
Event Application. (Ord. 2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
3-17-4: EXEMPTIONS:
A. The following are exempt from obtaining a special event permit, unless services are required by the
Village of Mokena:
1. The Village of Mokena, or events organized or sponsored by the Village of Mokena.
2. Educational institutions approved or authorized by the State of Illinois.
3. Block parties.
B. Notwithstanding the exemptions set forth in this section, issuance of other permits or licenses may be
required depending on the nature of the event, including but not limited to: amplifier permits, tent
permits, carnival/carnival ride permits, firework permits, bonfire permits, generator permits, and liquor
licenses.
C. Film production exemptions: Schools, businesses, places of worship, residents using their own
premises for producing films for their own educational, family, or training purposes, individuals filming
on public or private property for personal, non-commercial purposes, and the filming of actual news
events or stories within the Village of Mokena are exempt from obtaining a special event permit. (Ord.
2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
3-17-5: SPECIAL EVENTS DETERMINATION:
A special event shall not occur without the prior issuance of a permit pursuant to the terms and
conditions of this chapter. Upon receipt of a special events application, the Village will timely review the
application and advise whether a permit shall be issued. (Ord. 2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
3-17-6: CHARGE BACK FOR SPECIAL EVENTS:
After a special event is over, the Village may issue the applicant a bill for costs incurred by the Village,
including but not limited to reasonable personnel and security costs attributable to the special event and
for any damage caused to public property. The applicant shall be responsible for payment of said bill in
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 176/714
full within the timeframe specified on the bill. In the event that such payment is not made in full in a timely
manner, the Village Attorney may be requested by the Village Administrator to take or direct the
necessary legal action to obtain such payment. The reasonable costs and attorney's fees resulting from
such action shall be added to the amount due and owing by the applicant. Failure to timely pay bills for
charge back services may result in denial of future permits to the applicant or the applicant's
organization.
In addition to the requirements set forth in this Code and as set forth in the special event permit
application, events may be subject to additional conditions or restrictions deemed necessary and
appropriate by the Village. (Ord. 2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
3-17-7: SPECIAL EVENT CONDITIONS:
A. Fire And Life Safety: All special events must comply with State law and with this Code, ordinances,
rules, regulations, and policies.
B. Access To Event: There shall be in every permitted premises for major special events not less than
two (2) exits leading to the outside, each not less than three feet (3') in width and, if doors are
present, they are required to open outward.
C. Event Occupancy: Occupancy at a special event shall be in compliance with Village and State law.
D. Surrounding Area Of Event: The nature and intensity of the event must be planned so that the event
will be compatible with the existing development in the area of the event. The event shall not
significantly or materially be detrimental to the public health, safety, and welfare, or injurious to
property or improvements in the surrounding area, including, but not limited to, excess traffic, parking,
noise, pedestrian volume and safety, and adverse effects on neighboring areas.
E. Parking: Parking areas, both on and off street, for a particular event, are to be of adequate size,
properly located, and the entrance and exit drives shall be laid out so as to prevent traffic hazards and
nuisances.
F. Access For Inspections And Permitting Phases: A special event permittee shall allow free and
unobstructed access to the premises during the pre-inspection and permitting phases of event
approval by authorized Village personnel while acting on Village business.
G. Occupying Streets, Public Place Or Right-Of-Way: Any activity occupying or using any street, public
place, or public right-of-way in the Village may be allowed only in accordance with the provisions of
this Code where applicable.
H. Security: Security to be provided for a major special event, whether provided by private security
personnel and/or by the Mokena Police Department shall be evaluated and coordinated with the
Mokena Police Department. Security may be provided by private security personnel and/or by
members of the Mokena Police Department. If Mokena Police are used to assist with security for an
event, the applicant may be responsible for their costs, which will be assessed as part of the charge
back provided for in section 3-17-6 of this chapter.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 177/714
I. Smoking: Smoking on event premises shall be in compliance with State law.
J. Fundraising: Special events including fundraising activities shall comply with Village and State laws.
K. Carnivals And Circuses: Carnivals, carnival rides, and circuses shall comply in all respects with Village
ordinances, Code requirements, and State law.
L. Alcohol: If consumption of alcohol is proposed, said use must comply with Village and State law.
M. Animal Use Or Exhibition: If animal use or exhibition is proposed, said use must comply with Village
rules, regulations, ordinances, State law, and Federal law.
N. Location And Operation Conditions/Restrictions: In addition to the specific regulations, standards, and
time limitations set forth in this Code, all special events shall be subject to such conditions and
restrictions on their location and operation as deemed necessary from time to time by the Village
Administrator or his designee. (Ord. 2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
3-17-8: VIOLATION, PENALTY:
Any person who shall:
A. Organize a special event for which such permit has not been issued in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter; or,
B. Organize a special event contrary to or in violation of the provisions of the permit issued for such
special event; or,
C. Knowingly gives false information on the application for issuance of a special event permit as
provided in this chapter; or
D. In any other manner violate the provisions of this chapter;
shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense and such penalty may preclude the
issuance of future special event permits for that applicant or event. (Ord. 2019-O-003, 1-28-2019)
Chapter 18
MOBILE FOOD VENDORS
3-18-1: DEFINITIONS:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 178/714
The following words and phrases shall have the following meanings for the purposes of this chapter:
MOBILE FOOD VENDOR: Any person(s) who operates or sells food from a mobile cart, stationary cart,
pedal cart, trailer, van, or similar framework with or without an engine, or tent to the general public.
Catering operations scheduled by individual customers where food is not sold are excluded from the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-2: LICENSING:
Mobile food vendors shall be subject to the following licensing requirements:
A. All mobile food vendors must have a valid business license issued by the Village of Mokena prior to
conducting business in the Village.
B. As a condition of business license approval, all mobile food vendors must provide a valid copy of the
operating permit issued by the Will County Health Department, as well as a complete list of food
products sold by the vendor, a photo and/or detailed description of the mobile food vehicle(s), vehicle
identification number(s), and proof of liability insurance in accordance with section 3-18-8 of this
chapter.
C. A copy of the Village-issued business license shall be displayed in the mobile food vehicle at all times
while operating in the Village of Mokena. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-3: PERMITTING:
Mobile food vendors shall be subject to the following permit requirements:
A. In addition to obtaining a local business license, all mobile food vendors must apply for a "mobile food
vendor permit" for each event and shall only be valid for the date listed on the approved permit
application.
B. Every application for a "mobile food vendor permit" must include the vendor's contact information,
event date, hours of operation, and exact vending location.
C. Unless applied for by the property owner, every application for a "mobile food vendor permit" must
include a signed letter of authorization from the property owner specifying the date of the event, hours
of operation, vendor name, and exact vending location.
D. A copy of the approved "mobile food vendor permit" must be kept on the mobile food vehicle at all
times while operating in the Village of Mokena. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-4: FREQUENCY:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 179/714
A. All "mobile food vendor permits" shall be limited to one day per calendar week, unless authorized by
the Village as part of a special event.
B. All businesses licensed by the Village of Mokena shall be limited to no more than four (4) "mobile food
vendor permits" annually, unless authorized by the Village. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-5: HOURS OF OPERATION:
A. In all Residentially-Zoned Districts, mobile food operations shall be limited to the hours of seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. Monday - Sunday.
B. In all Commercial and Industrially-Zoned Districts, mobile food operations shall be limited to the hours
of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight Monday - Saturday, and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on Sundays. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-6: FEES:
A. The business license fee for mobile food vendors shall be thirty six dollars ($36.00), and must be
renewed annually.
B. The permit fee for a "mobile food vendor permit" shall hereby be set at twenty five dollars ($25.00) per
application. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-7: REGULATIONS:
Mobile food vendors shall be subject to the following regulations:
A. Mobile food vehicles are prohibited from parking on public streets and/or publicly-owned property,
unless authorized by the Village.
B. Mobile food vending operations shall be restricted to the location provided on the approved "mobile
food vendor permit".
C. All mobile food vendors are prohibited from passing through the community in search of customers.
D. Mobile food vendors shall be prohibited from verbally soliciting business from pedestrians or persons
in vehicles, and shall not sell to persons in vehicles.
E. All mobile food vendors must maintain a minimum setback distance of two hundred feet (200') from
the primary entrance of other food service establishments unless written consent is provided by the
proprietor(s) of such food service establishments.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 180/714
F. Mobile food vehicles shall not obstruct or interfere with the free flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic,
including but not limited to access to or from any business, public building, dwelling unit, and
emergency access or fire lanes, nor shall it restrict sight distance at driveways and intersections.
G. Stationed vehicles must be at least fifteen feet (15') from fire hydrants and Fire Department
connections.
H. Vehicles shall not occupy any handicap accessible parking space(s).
I. Service windows must be faced away from drive aisles and traffic lanes.
J. All signage must be permanently affixed to the mobile food vehicle.
K. All equipment and associated operations shall be self-contained within the mobile food vehicle.
L. Amplified music and loud noises are prohibited from projecting from the mobile food vehicle.
M. Mobile food vendors shall provide refuse containers for the public.
N. Mobile food vendors shall be responsible for controlling smoke and odors caused by food preparation
so as to avoid a public nuisance.
O. Mobile food vendors shall be responsible for organizing customer queuing in a manner that maintains
a clear path along the sidewalk and does not interfere with or obstruct the free passage of
pedestrians.
P. The sale or service of alcohol by a mobile food vendor is strictly prohibited unless temporary liquor
license approval has been granted by the Village. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-8: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
All mobile food vendors applying for a business license shall produce proof to the Village that such
applicant has obtained commercial general liability insurance, with limits of not less than one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence, for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage and
obtained a commercial automobile liability insurance with limits of not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) combined single limit, per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage arising in
any way from the issuance of the license or activities conducted pursuant to the license. The insurance
policy required under this section shall: a) be issued by an insurer authorized to insure in Illinois; b) name
the Village of Mokena as additional insured on a primary, noncontributory basis for any liability arising
directly or indirectly from the licensee's operations; and c) include a provision requiring thirty (30)
calendar days' advance notice to the Village prior to cancellation or lapse of the policy. If a mobile food
vendor license is issued to such applicant, such licensee shall maintain the insurance required under this
section in full force and effect for the duration of the license period. The licensee shall also keep proof of
the required insurance in the mobile food vehicle at all times when the vehicle is in use and, upon
demand, shall produce such proof for inspection by an authorized Village official. Failure to comply with
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 181/714
the requirements of this section shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license. (Ord.
2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-9: EXEMPTIONS:
The following are exempt from mobile food vendor regulations:
A. Delivery or distribution of food, goods, or products ordered or purchased by customers from a point of
sale other than a mobile food vendor.
B. Mobile food vendors operating in a Residentially-zoned area shall be exempt from the requirement to
obtain a "mobile food vendor permit". All other licensing and operational requirements outlined in this
chapter shall apply.
C. Mobile food vendors serving a site that is actively under construction pursuant to a valid building
permit, and do not vend to the general public during their stop.
D. Mobile food vendors operating as part of a special event shall comply with the requirements outlined
in section 3-18-10 of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-10: SPECIAL EVENTS:
The requirements of this section shall apply to mobile food vendors operating as part of a special event
authorized by the Village.
A. Definitions: The following words and phrases shall have the following meanings for the purposes of
this section:
MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE: A fully-enclosed vehicle or trailer equipped with facilities for preparing,
cooking, and selling various food products and operating at an approved fixed location as an
extension of a retail food establishment.
B. Special Event Requirements: Any mobile food vendors operating a mobile food vehicle as part of a
special event shall be subject to the following requirements:
1. All licensing requirements outlined in section 3-18-2 of this chapter.
2. Mobile food vending operations shall be restricted to the location provided on the approved "special
event permit".
3. Mobile food vehicles shall not obstruct or interfere with the free flow of pedestrian or vehicular
traffic, including but not limited to access to or from any business, public building, dwelling unit, and
emergency access or fire lanes, nor shall it restrict sight distance at driveways and intersections.
4. Stationed vehicles must be at least fifteen feet (15') from fire hydrants and Fire Department
connections.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 182/714
5. Vehicles shall not occupy any handicap accessible parking space(s).
6. Mobile food vendors shall be responsible for organizing customer queuing in a manner that
maintains a clear path along the sidewalk and does not interfere with or obstruct the free passage
of pedestrians.
7. The sale or service of alcohol by a mobile food vendor is strictly prohibited unless temporary liquor
license approval has been granted by the Village.
C. Exemptions: The following exemptions shall apply to mobile food vendors operating as part of a
special event authorized by the Village:
1. Mobile food operations which do not involve the use of a mobile food vehicle, as defined by this
section, shall be exempt from the licensing requirements outlined in section 3-18-2 of this chapter.
2. All mobile food vendors listed on the approved "special event permit" shall be exempt from the
permit requirements outlined in section 3-18-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
3-18-11: VIOLATION, PENALTY:
Any person who shall:
A. Operate a mobile food vendor vehicle pursuant to section 3-18-1 of this chapter for which such
permit has not been issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; or,
B. Knowingly gives false information on the application for issuance of a mobile food vendor permit
provided in this chapter; or
C. In any other manner violate the provisions of this chapter;
Shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 2019-O-019, 5-28-2019)
Title 4
PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY
Chapter 1
NUISANCES
4-1-1: NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any person within the limits of the village to engage in, create,
cause, allow to exist, encourage, cause or help to cause any of the following acts or conditions set forth
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 183/714
in this section, all of which are hereby defined as nuisances. It shall be unlawful for any person: (1983
Code; amd. Ord. 2008-O-005, 1-14-2008)
A. To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected,
deposited or to remain in any place, to the prejudice of others.
B. To throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter, or the carcass of any dead animal in any
watercourse, lake, pond, spring, well or common sewer, street or public highway.
C. To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any spring, river, stream, pond or lake, to
the injury or prejudice of others.
D. To obstruct or impede, without legal authority, the passage of any navigable river or waters.
E. To obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places,
and ways to burying places.
F. To carry on the business of manufacturing gunpowder, nitroglycerin, or other highly explosive
substances, or mixing or grinding the materials therefor, in any building within twenty (20) rods of any
valuable building erected at the time such business may be commenced.
G. To erect, continue or use any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or
manufacture, which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive smells or otherwise, is offensive or
dangerous to the health of individuals, or of the public.
H. To advertise wares or occupation by painting notices of the same on, or affixing them to fences or
other private property, or on rocks or other natural objects, without the consent of the owner, or if in
the highway or other public place, without permission of the proper authorities.
I. To harass, intimidate or threaten any person who is about to sell or lease or has sold or leased a
residence or other real property or is about to buy or lease or has bought or leased a residence or
other real property, when the harassment, intimidation or threat relates to a person's attempt to sell,
buy or lease a residence or other real property, or refers to a person's sale, purchase or lease of a
residence or other real property.
J. To allow water to accumulate and remain in a pond or ponds either wholly or partly within the limits of
any private property for a period of more than ten (10) consecutive days. For the purpose of this
section, the term "pond" shall be considered to mean any exposed surface of water not less than one
hundred (100) square feet in area which has accumulated either by natural or artificial means, in any
depression or connected series of depressions or depressions of excavations, whether existing
naturally or created artificially.
K. To allow any person to throw or drop a cup, plate, trash, paper, waste, refuse, garbage, litter or
container upon private or public sidewalks, crosswalks, roadways, property or any part of any public
street or alley.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 184/714
L. To own, use or keep any horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, swine or domestic fowl of the species of
geese, ducks, turkeys, hens or barn fowl, guinea fowl, peacocks, pigeons or bees within the village
limits, except when specifically allowed by ordinance.
M. To permit the growth upon any premises of any noxious weeds, such as jimson, burdock, ragweed,
thistle, cocklebur and like weeds1.
N. To cause or suffer grass, leaves, underbrush or other combustible matter to be collected, deposited or
to remain on his premises in such quantities and in such condition as to materially increase the
danger to property of others from forest or other fires.
O. To permit the growth upon any premises of any poplar or cottonwood trees as herein defined. A
"poplar tree" is hereby defined as any of a genus of slender quick growing salicaceous trees also
known as populus. A "cottonwood tree" is hereby defined as a tree of the poplar group with a cottony
comma investing the seeds, also known as Populus balsamifera.
P. To permit or maintain an unsightly yard or premises where there is an accumulation or deposit of any
vehicle, equipment, household furniture such as refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, or waste
material of any nature; to maintain an unsightly yard or area where wrecked or disabled automobiles,
trucks or equipment, or other such matter is allowed to accumulate.
Q. To use, operate or maintain any housecar or trailer for human habitation upon any lot or plat of ground
within the limits of the village, except in a duly licensed trailer camp.
R. To commit any offense which is a nuisance according to the common law of the law of the land or
made such by the statutes of the state. (1983 Code)
S. To permit or maintain an unsightly yard or premises where there is an accumulation or deposit of
discarded and unwanted putrescible and nonputrescible household and kitchen wastes, including, but
not limited to, food, food residues, and materials necessarily used for packaging, storing, preparing,
and consuming same, usually defined as "garbage"; and all combustible and noncombustible waste
materials resulting from the routine of domestic housekeeping, including, but not limited to, aluminum
and steel cans, glass containers, plastic containers, medical waste generated as general household
waste, metal, paper of all types, including newspapers, books, magazines and catalogs, boxes and
cartons; cold ashes; furniture, furnishings, and fixtures; textiles and leather; dead animals and animal
waste; toys and recreational equipment; and similar items.
T. To wilfully make or assist in the making of any loud, intensive, repetitive, unnecessary or unusual noise
or noises, caused by any horn, bell, radio, loudspeaker, vehicle, motorcycle, dirt bike, recreational
activity, or other instrument or activity. (Ord. 2008-O-005, 1-14-2008)
U. To allow any garbage/recycling/landscape waste containers to be stored other than in, behind, or
alongside of the principal or accessory building on a lot in a neat and orderly fashion.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 185/714
V. To allow a garbage/recycling/landscape waste container to be placed at the curb for collection sooner
than five o'clock (5:00) P.M. the evening prior to collection day or later than seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.
on collection day. (Ord. 2014-O-015, 4-28-2014)
Chapter 2
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section:
ALTERNATE GARBAGE DEVICE: This is any disposable container that can be disposal utilized in place
of the primary garbage disposal device with prior approval of the village for legitimate circumstances. It is
designed to be for alternate use when the primary garbage disposal device is, for legitimate reasons, not
a viable option for the resident. These containers must consist of a container with a lid of not more than
thirty (30) gallons, or other containers that are enclosed as to prevent garbage from blowing away (such
as enclosed boxes or closed secure plastic garbage bags). These can only be used with prior approval of
the village.
GARBAGE: Rejected food wastes, including every waste accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable
matter as used or intended for food, and such material as may necessarily be used for wrapping.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: Includes, but is not limited to, such landscape waste as grass, grass clippings,
shrubbery, brush and shrub branches, leaves, trees, wood chips, plants, weeds, bushes, tree limbs or
branches and any and all types of other similar materials or parts thereof. Can also be referred to as
"yard waste".
PRIMARY GARBAGE DISPOSAL DEVICE: The cart issued to village residential dwelling units, by the
village's waste hauler, that the village provides residents to dispose of garbage. Carts are brown in color
and will not be more than ninety five (95) gallons, but may be exchanged for a smaller cart of sixty five
(65) gallons or thirty five (35) gallons after the original cart is delivered.
PRIMARY RECYCLING DISPOSAL DEVICE: The cart issued to village residential dwelling units, by the
village's waste hauler, that the village provides residents to dispose of their recyclables. Carts are green
in color and will be sixty five (65) gallons, but may be exchanged for a larger cart of ninety five (95)
gallons or a smaller cart of thirty five (35) gallons after the original cart is delivered.
RECYCLABLE MATERIALS: Aluminum, tin/steel cans, newspaper print, clear, amber, or green glass
bottles/containers, shiny glossy magazines, phone books, chipboard, cardboard, discarded mail and
types 1 and 2 plastic or any other materials as set forth from time to time by the village board.
REFUSE: All solid waste of a community, including garbage, rubbish, and construction wastes, including
discarded furniture and large appliances.
RESIDENTIAL DWELLING UNIT: Rooms located within a dwelling structure and used as a single
habitable unit with facilities which are used or are intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, and
eating. Each individual residential dwelling unit within a townhouse or condominium building not
exceeding twelve (12) units shall fall within the terms and provisions of this chapter. Any apartment
building exceeding three (3) apartments is to receive an individual apartment rate as hereinafter set forth.
RUBBISH: Such matter including, but not limited to, ashes, cans, metalware, glass, crockery, paper,
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 186/714
boxes, rags and old clothing, wood, dirt, dust, sweepings, or litter of any kind.
SECONDARY GARBAGE OR RECYCLING DISPOSAL DEVICE: This is any container utilized for
overflow of garbage or recycling that does not fit into the primary garbage or recycling disposal device. It
is designed to be for incidental use when the primary garbage or recycling disposal device is fully utilized.
These containers must consist of a garbage container with a lid of not more than thirty (30) gallons, or
other containers that are enclosed as to prevent garbage from blowing away (such as enclosed boxes or
closed secure plastic garbage bags).
VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR: The village administrator of the village, and his or her authorized agent.
(Ord. 2006-O-011, 3-27-2006)
4-2-2: ACCUMULATION OF REFUSE; DUMPING:
A. Accumulation: The owner, occupant or lessee of any premises in the village shall cause to be removed
from said premises all refuse and shall keep said premises at all times free and clean from any
accumulation of refuse.
B. Dumping: No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, leave, cause, or permit the dumping,
depositing, dropping, throwing, discarding or leaving of garbage, refuse, rubbish, or yard waste upon
any public property, or private property without the permission of the owner, within the village, unless:
1. The property has been designated by the village for the disposal of garbage, refuse, rubbish or
yard waste;
2. The person is acting under the direction of proper public officials during special cleanup days; or
3. The person is lawfully acting in or reacting to an emergency situation where health and safety is
threatened, and removes and properly disposes of such garbage, refuse, rubbish or yard waste
when the emergency situation no longer exists. (Ord. 1261, 9-23-1991)
4-2-3: REFUSE STORAGE REGULATIONS:
A. Types Of Approved Containers:
1. All residential dwellings, townhomes and condominiums shall be referred to herein as a "residential
dwelling unit" and are required to place all refuse in a primary garbage disposal device provided by
the village's contracted waste hauler (unless an alternate garbage disposal device has been
approved by the village). Excess garbage, rubbish or waste that does not fit into the container
during a regular scheduled pick up may be placed next to the provided cart in a secondary garbage
or recycling disposal device.
2. All recyclable materials shall be placed in a primary recycling disposal device provided by the
village's contracted recycling hauler. Excess recycling that does not fit into the container during a
regular scheduled pick up may be placed next to the provided cart in a secondary garbage or
recycling disposal device.
3. All owners, management or leasing agents of apartments that are being leased or rented must
provide at least one leakproof container (or equivalent thereof) of one cubic yard capacity for every
six (6) units or less. Container locations and methods must be acceptable to the administrator or his
authorized representative.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 187/714
4. All institutional, commercial, industrial and construction refuse shall be stored in durable, rust
resisting, nonabsorbent, watertight and easily washable containers, which shall have close fitting
covers and adequate handles to facilitate collection. No more than four (4) 30-gallon containers
shall be allowed for each institution, commercial or industrial establishment. If more than four (4)
are required to store garbage or refuse between collection periods, it shall be required to provide at
least one cubic yard capacity or as many as is necessary to provide storage between collection
periods.
5. Yard waste shall be placed in either an approved contractor provided one hundred five (105) gallon
cart or residents may use thirty (30) gallon biodegradable bags provided such bags can be handled
and loaded by one man without breakage or tearing and that such bag has the contractor's
collection sticker affixed to it.
6. In addition thereto, all owners of residential dwelling units are entitled to the following solid waste
items being collected on their regular collection day from the normal place of collection (in a
manner and frequency not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter): discarded furniture,
appliances, mattresses, beds, bedsprings, tables, chairs, washers, dryers, refrigerators, stoves,
and any other large household items; provided that in no event shall the occupant of the residential
dwelling unit deposit more than one of the aforementioned solid waste items for collection on any
single collection day.
B. Containers Maintained In Sanitary Condition: Containers as herein described and provided by the
village or its designated hauler shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and kept clean by the user,
and be used as described herein.
C. Inspection Of Containers: All refuse, yard waste, and recyclable material containers shall be subject to
inspection and approval or disapproval by the village administrator or his authorized agent. In the
event of disapproval of any such container, it shall be the duty of the owner (or village contractor)
thereof to procure an acceptable container within seven (7) days of notice of disapproval. (Ord. 2006-
O-011, 3-27-2006)
D. Permitted Location For Containers: Except when placed at the curb for collection,
garbage/recycling/landscape containers shall be stored in, behind, or alongside of the principal or
accessory buildings on a lot in a neat and orderly fashion. (Ord. 2014-O-015, 4-28-2014)
4-2-4: GARBAGE AND RECYCLING PROGRAM:
A. Initial Distribution And Replacement Of Garbage And Recycling Carts: All residential dwelling units
within the corporate boundaries of the village will initially be issued one 95-gallon brown garbage cart
and one 65-gallon green recycling cart per residential unit at the time of issuance of a certificate of
occupancy for new residential construction or at the time of annexation of existing residential property
to the village. The cost of replacement of said garbage and recycling carts shall be borne by the
village's designated waste and recycling hauler as determined by the village's public works director or
his designee or on an as needed basis. In cases of damage due to negligence, the cost of
replacement will be the responsibility of the user.
B. Recycling In Containers Required: It is the goal of the village board of trustees to reduce volume in the
area landfills and, therefore, encourage recycling. Recycling will only be collected from the primary
recycling disposal device and the fee for the collection of recyclable materials at residential dwelling
units shall be set from time to time by the village board of trustees.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 188/714
C. Commingling Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to:
1. Place refuse, yard waste or waste materials other than recyclable materials in any recycling bin.
2. Place refuse material in anything other than approved refuse container.
3. Place yard waste in anything other than an approved yard waste container.
4. Place refuse generated by residential properties into commercial or industrial property refuse
containers.
5. Commingle yard waste materials with refuse or recyclable materials.
D. Title To Garbage And Recycling Carts: All garbage and recycling carts provided by the village or its
designated hauler shall remain the property of the village or its designated hauler and shall not be
removed from the property on which the dwelling unit is located without the prior written consent of
the village administrator or his designee.
E. Charge For Pick Up Of All Waste Materials: All owners of residential dwelling units within the village
will be billed by the village for the pick up and disposal of refuse and recyclable materials at a rate as
set from time to time by the village board.
F. Title To Wastes: Except for the original owner thereof, who may redeem the same, all recyclable
materials and refuse materials collected in accordance with the terms hereof shall become and be
property of the village as soon as they are placed at the curb or parkway.
G. Unlawful Removal Of Refuse Or Recyclable Materials: Except for the original owner thereof and/or a
refuse or recycling collector authorized by or under contract with the village, it shall be unlawful for
any person, firm or corporation, to remove any item of refuse or recyclable material placed in or
adjacent to village refuse or recycling containers.
H. Unlawful Damage To Or Removal Of Provided Recycling Or Garbage Carts: Except as authorized by
the village administrator, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to remove, damage,
destroy or deface any garbage or recycling carts that are owned and provided by the village or its
waste and recycling hauler. (Ord. 2006-O-011, 3-27-2006)
4-2-5: COLLECTION SCHEDULES:
A. All household, institutional, commercial industrial, and construction refuse, yard waste and recyclable
materials shall be collected at least once each week.
B. No refuse, yard waste and/or recyclable material containers may be placed in a front yard or parkway,
except during the period from five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the evening prior to collection or to the
evening of collection day. No such container may be left in a front yard or parkway after seven o'clock
(7:00) P.M. of collection day. No such containers shall be placed so as to constitute a nuisance to
adjacent property or occupants thereof. In all cases when such a container is placed on the rear of
the lot for the purpose of having its contents removed, it shall be entirely within the lot line. (Ord.
1261, 9-23-1991)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 189/714
4-2-6: REGULATION OF COLLECTORS:
A. Subject to the provisions of this chapter and except as otherwise by ordinance provided for, the village
may provide for the disposal of household garbage and other refuse, as above defined, by contract
with a contracted disposal service.
B. The contracted disposal service shall make collections once a week for refuse and once every other
week for recycling, between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on a day
designated by agreement between the village and the contracted disposal service. There shall be no
change in the day of collection except upon written notification by said contractor to the village or
village to said contractor and upon notice to each owner, occupant or lessee receiving garbage
disposal service under this chapter and any contract in implementation thereof, in any reasonable
manner available to the village.
C. Contracted disposal services for any entity throughout the village shall be restricted to the hours
between six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
D. The service charge for commercial business or industry shall be collected by and paid directly to the
contracted disposal service. The service charged to owners, occupants or lessees for the collection
and disposal of household garbage, refuse, rubbish and recyclables shall be paid to the village in
such sums or amounts as are determined from time to time. (The village treasurer shall be
responsible for issuing bills and maintaining the books of collection.) The service charge for pick up of
yard waste will be solely between the contracted disposal service and village residents. (Ord. 2006-O-
011, 3-27-2006)
4-2-7: COLLECTION EQUIPMENT:
A. Vehicles used for the collection or disposal of garbage, or of refuse containing garbage, shall have
liquidtight, enclosed metal bodies of easily cleanable construction, shall be cleaned at sufficient
frequency to prevent nuisance of insect breeding, and shall be maintained in good repair.
B. All public or private vehicles used for the collection or disposal of rubbish or yard waste may have
open bodies, provided that suitable provisions are made to prevent the scattering of the contents.
(Ord. 1261, 9-23-1991)
4-2-8: CONTRACT SERVICE:
In its discretion, the board of trustees may ask for and accept bids from a private contractor for the
collection of refuse in the village. In the event such contract is entered into, said contractor shall be
subject to the regulations of said board as to the manner and method of collection and disposal of
garbage and rubbish and no other private person, firm or corporation shall be permitted to furnish said
service to the village. (Ord. 1261, 9-23-1991)
4-2-9: PENALTY:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 190/714
Any person found guilty of a violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the penalty
provisions of title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 1261, 9-23-1991)
Chapter 3
WEEDS
4-3-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, the word "weeds" shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
burdock, giant ragweed, common ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, jimson, blue vervain, common milkweed,
wild lettuce, curled dock, all varieties of smart weeds, poison hemlock, wild hemp, and all grasses and
other vegetation except trees and shrubs, and vegetable and flower gardens maintained in such
condition as to not create a nuisance. (Ord. 1643, 5-24-1999)
4-3-2: DUTY TO CUT WEEDS:
A. Every owner of real estate within the village shall cut weeds on his property at such times as may be
necessary so that the weeds shall not exceed eight inches (8") in height; if the owner neglects or
refuses to cut weeds, so that the weeds exceed eight inches (8") in height, the village may cut the
weeds or authorize some person to cut the weeds on behalf of the village.
B. It is hereby declared to be illegal for the owners of real estate to refuse or neglect to cut weeds when
the weeds have reached a height in excess of eight inches (8"). All weeds, however, shall be cut,
pulled or destroyed by the owner or person in charge or control of the real estate at least two (2)
times per year, once between May 1 and June 15, and once again between July 1 and August 15, in
addition to any other times necessary to keep the weeds from attaining a height of eight inches (8").
(Ord. 630, 6-22-1971)
4-3-3: WEED CUTTING LIEN:
A. If weeds are cut by the village or by someone directed to cut them on behalf of the village pursuant to
this chapter, a notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred by the village shall be recorded
in the manner prescribed by this section.
B. The village or the person performing the service by authority of the village, in its or his own name, may
file notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds. The notice of lien shall consist of a
sworn statement setting out the following information:
1. A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof;
2. The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service;
3. The date when such cost and expense was incurred by the village.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 191/714
C. The sworn statement shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense is incurred. (Ord.
630, 6-22-1971)
4-3-4: NOTICE TO PROPERTY OWNER:
After the cutting of weeds on any premises by the village, the village shall send notice of the same to the
person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the last preceding year, by
personal service or by certified mail. The notice shall identify the property by common description, and
the location of the weeds cut. In addition, the notice shall state the substance of this chapter, including
the fact that a lien has been or will be filed with the Will County recorder of deeds. (Ord. 1643, 5-24-
1999)
4-3-5: PAYMENT OF COSTS AND EXPENSES; RELEASE OF LIEN:
Upon payment of the costs incurred and the expense of weed cutting, after notice of the lien has been
filed pursuant to this chapter, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien
has been filed and the release shall be filed of record in the same manner as filing notice of the lien.
(Ord. 630, 6-22-1971; amd. Ord. 1643, 5-24-1999)
4-3-6: PENALTY:
Any owner or person in charge or control of any real estate found to be in violation of any provision of this
chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 1643, 5-24-1999)
Chapter 4
EXPLOSIVES AND FIREWORKS
4-4-1: DEFINITION:
"Fireworks" means any combustible or explosive composition, any substance or combination of
substances, or any article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary
exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion, deflagration, or detonation, and shall include blank
cartridges, toy cannons in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath
to propel them, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, or other fireworks of like
construction, any fireworks containing any explosive compound, or any tablets or other device containing
any explosive substance or containing combustible substances producing visual effects. However, the
term "fireworks" shall not include toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or
plastic caps containing 0.25 grain or less of explosive compound are used, provided they are so
constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion, and toy
pistol paper or plastic caps which contain less than 0.20 grain of explosive mixture, the sale and use of
which shall be permitted at all times. (Ord. 2006-O-037, 6-26-2006)
4-4-2: UNLAWFUL TO SELL, POSSESS, OR USE; EXCEPTIONS:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 192/714
A. Regulations:
1. Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, copartnership, or
corporation to offer for sale, display for sale, sell at retail, provide storage for, use, possess,
manufacture, or explode any fireworks within the Village or allow any such acts on property owned
by that person, firm, copartnership, or corporation within the Village. However, the President and
Board of Trustees shall have the right to issue a permit for supervised public displays of fireworks,
provided the applicant for such permit complies with the regulations established in section 4-4-4 of
this chapter for the issuance of such a permit.
2. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit the use of fireworks by railroads,
public utilities, public and private carriers, or other transportation agencies, for signal purposes or
illumination, or the use of blank cartridges for a show or theater, for signal, ceremonial purposes in
athletics or sports, or for use by veteran or military organizations.
3. It shall be unlawful to keep or store any dynamite in the Village.
4. It shall be unlawful to keep or store any nitroglycerin or the explosive commonly known as TNT in
the Village in any quantities, excepting for medical or laboratory purposes, and for such purposes
no more than one-fourth (1/4) ounce shall be stored in any one building or premises.
5. It shall be unlawful to keep or store any black powder or gunpowder or guncotton in excess of five
(5) pounds on any one premises in the Village.
B. Violations: Any property owner or person in charge or control of any explosives or fireworks found to
be in violation of any provision of this chapter shall be fined as follows for each violation in a single
calendar year:
First violation $ 25.00
Second violation 250.00
Third and subsequent violations 750.00
A separate offense shall be deemed committed during or on any day on which a violation occurs or
continues. (Ord. 2018-O-010, 6-11-2018)
4-4-3: RULES OF THE STATE FIRE MARSHAL:
All explosives kept or stored in the Village shall be kept and stored in accordance with the rules enforced
by the State Fire Marshal, with regard thereto. (Ord. 2006-O-037, 6-26-2006)
4-4-4: PUBLIC FIREWORKS DISPLAYS:
A. The supervised public display of fireworks may be permitted under the following conditions:
1. Each pyrotechnic display and/or public fireworks display shall be conducted by a licensed lead
pyrotechnic operator, who shall be responsible for the setup and firing of the display and
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 193/714
supervision of personnel and who is licensed pursuant to the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator
Licensing Act1.
2. Applications for a permit shall be made to the village in writing at least fifteen (15) days in advance
of the date of the pyrotechnic/fireworks display, unless agreed to otherwise by the village and the
fire chief of the jurisdiction in which the display will occur.
3. The person in charge of a public fireworks display (lead operator) must be in possession of, and be
able to produce, his/her license upon request at all times during delivery, setup and performance of
the display and should have a copy of the permit in his possession.
4. A permit shall be issued only after the chief of the fire department providing fire protection coverage
to the area of display, or his or her designee, has inspected the site and determined that the display
can be performed in full compliance with the rules adopted by the state fire marshal and that the
display shall not be hazardous to property or endanger any person or persons.
5. Permits shall be signed by the chief of the fire department providing fire protection to the area of
the display or his or her designee, and must identify the lead pyrotechnic operator.
6. Due to the hazardous nature of materials involved, no fireworks should be stored on location prior
to setup and showtime.
7. Persons setting up and shooting the fireworks display, including assistants, should be at least
eighteen (18) years of age, and experienced and professional shooters.
8. Sufficient security should be provided to keep all persons except authorized persons and those in
actual charge of the display at least five hundred feet (500') from display or during setup and firing.
9. The supplier of the fireworks should have a current Illinois permit number.
10. There shall be no trees, utility poles, or any type of obstruction within fifty feet (50') of the firing
range and shall be no less than two hundred feet (200') from railroads, highways, or general public
or other structures, nor six hundred feet (600') from any school, church, hospital, asylum, or
infirmary.
11. The grass must be wetted down around the mortar eight (8) hours before firing. There shall be
one mortar loader for each six (6) mortars.
12. The fire protection district shall be at the sight of the firing with a minimum of one engine that is
properly manned. A fire extinguisher and/or water hose must be present while fireworks are being
prepared for firing or fired.
13. Mortar holes are to be drilled in a minimum of three-fourths (3/4) of length of the mortar and dirt is
to be packed around the mortar.
14. Mortars shall be two feet (2') apart with a minimum distance of six feet (6') between mortars of
different sizes.
15. Loaders and shooters shall wear tightfitting, noncombustible clothing and shall not have been
under the influence of alcoholic beverages, drugs, or controlled substances for twelve (12) hours
before firing.
16. No firing shall take place if the wind is at twenty (20) miles per hour or above, or if at the request
of the village the fire protection district determines that ground conditions are such that if the firing
were to take place there would be a hazard to the immediate or surrounding area of the display.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 194/714
17. All aerial displays shall be kept in wooden boxes with self-closing covers with a maximum size of
thirty six inches by twenty four inches by twenty four inches (36" x 24" x 24"), and two inches (2")
off the ground. Boxes shall be a minimum of ten feet (10') from the mortars.
18. The fireworks company and/or sponsoring organization shall file its/their application for a permit
for supervised fireworks displays at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the display date. The
application shall:
a. Contain, and any permit issued shall be subject to, an undertaking by the fireworks company and
sponsoring organization to indemnify and hold harmless the village, fire protection district, the
park district and their officers, employees and agents from and against any and all liability in any
way arising out of or resulting from the fireworks display.
b. Be accompanied by a certificate of insurance in a sum not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) from an insurer authorized to do business in Illinois and which shall insure the
applicant against liabilities, judgments, costs, damages and expenses that may accrue against,
be charged to or be recovered from the applicant on the reason of damage to property or injury to
or death of any person arising from the pyrotechnic display or flame effect display. Such
insurance coverage shall be an occurrence based policy, and it shall cover all periods of time
when pyrotechnic materials, including flame effect materials, are in the insured's actual or
constructive possession, including those times when the materials are being stored, transported,
handled, used, discharged and displayed. This certificate of insurance shall name the village, the
fire district, the park district and their officers, agents and employees as additional insureds. In
addition, the certificate shall specifically state on its face that the general liability coverage
includes coverage relative to firework displays and that the policies shall remain in effect for at
least thirty (30) days after the firing.
19. The application for a permit for a supervised public display of fireworks shall be accompanied by a
cash bond, in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned upon compliance with
all applicable village codes and ordinances.
20. The supplier of the fireworks shall be responsible for the recovery of fireworks (aerial displays that
did not fire).
a. Recovery or the search for unfired displays shall start immediately or, at a minimum, at sunrise.
b. The area of a misfired shell shall be guarded by the display company at their cost from the time
of the misfiring until the discovery of the shell.
c. The cost of recovering the shell shall be borne by the fireworks supplier and/or dealer.
21. The supervised fireworks display must be conducted in full compliance with NFPA standard 1126
(2001), use of pyrotechnics before a proximate audience, which is incorporated herein by
reference, to the extent the standard is applicable to the specific display.
22. The supervised fireworks display must be conducted in full compliance with NFPA standard 1123
(2000), code for fireworks display, which is incorporated herein by reference, to the extent the
standard is applicable to the specific display.
23. All supervised fireworks displays which are conducted outdoors shall be electronically ignited.
24. In the event that the village grants a permit for indoor fireworks, the building in which the display
will occur must meet one of the following requirements: a) the building must be protected
throughout, including both the seating area and the stage, by an automatic sprinkler system; or b)
the stage must be protected by an automatic sprinkler system and have a proscenium curtain, as
required by NFPA life safety code (2000), that will automatically deploy in the event of a fire. No
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 195/714
special effects fireworks device and/or flame effect device may be set up on the stage forward of
the curtain (on the audience side of the curtain).
B. After a permit has been issued under these rules and regulations, the possession, sale, use and
distribution of fireworks for such a display shall be lawful for that purpose only. No permit granted
hereunder shall be transferable. (Ord. 2006-O-037, 6-26-2006)
Chapter 5
OPEN BURNING
4-5-1: OPEN BURNING RESTRICTED:
A. Nuisance Declared: The open burning of any garbage, refuse, rubbish, recyclable materials, and yard
waste at any place within the limits of the village is hereby declared a public nuisance and is
prohibited. For purposes of this subsection, the terms "garbage", "refuse", "rubbish", "yard waste" and
"recyclable materials" shall have the meanings ascribed to them by chapter 2 of this title. For
purposes of this subsection, "open burning" refers to outdoor fires and not to fires contained within
indoor fireplaces or stoves.
B. Exceptions:
1. Recreational Fires: Recreational fires shall constitute an exception to the above prohibition. For this
purpose, "recreational fire" is defined as an outdoor fire which is used to cook food for human
consumption and which may be fueled by such combustible material such as small twigs, limbs,
and branches which would otherwise be prohibited under subsection A of this section.
2. Mason's Fires: Mason's fires shall constitute an exception to the above prohibition. For this purpose
"mason's fire" is defined as an outdoor fire which is used to prepare sand mortar and which may be
fueled by such untreated combustible material as scrap wood in natural form, not to exceed two
feet (2') in length, which would otherwise be prohibited under subsection A of this section. (Ord.
1460, 7-24-1995)
4-5-2: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of a violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the penalty
provisions of title 1, chapter 4 of this code. In addition, the village attorney shall petition the court to
require any person found guilty of a violation of the provisions of this chapter, whose conduct proximately
caused an incident resulting in an appropriate emergency response, to make restitution to the public
agency responsible for such emergency response. Such restitution shall not exceed five hundred dollars
($500.00) per public agency for each such emergency response. For the purpose of this section,
"emergency response" shall mean any incident requiring a response by a fire district or department or
ambulance service. (Ord. 1460, 7-24-1995)

PESTICIDE APPLICATION

The spraying or other application of pesticides for mosquitos on all public property or public rights of way

Spraying or other application of pesticides for mosquitos is permitted when deemed by the corporate
authorities of the village to be in its best interest. (Ord. 1321, 9-28-1992)
Chapter 7
EASEMENTS FOR STORM WATER DRAINAGE OR
DETENTION
4-7-1: ALTERATION OR MODIFICATION OF DRAINAGE OR DETENTION
EASEMENTS:
No owner, renter or person in possession or control of any property within the corporate limits of the
village shall, with respect to any easement rights for drainage and/or storm water detention owned by the
village which affect said property:
A. Alter or modify, or permit to be altered or modified, the elevation within any such designated
easement (as originally established by the subdivisions plans approved by village);
B. Construct or place, or permit to be constructed or placed, any structures, accessory buildings,
fencing, fill, landscaping, gardens, waste material or trash, within any such designated easement;
C. Otherwise take any action, or permit any action to be taken which would adversely affect the
elevations or flow of water within any such designated easement.
It shall be the responsibility of each property owner to maintain that portion of any and all such
designated storm water detention and/or drainage easement(s) located upon the owner's property; and
keep the easement(s) in good order and condition. (Ord. 1349, 7-26-93)

Any person found guilty of a violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the following
penalty provisions:
A. Fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 197/714
B. The village may record a notice of violation of this chapter.
C. The village may make application to the circuit court for an injunction or other appropriate court
order requiring conformance with this chapter.
Nothing herein shall prevent the village from taking such other lawful action to prevent or remedy any
violations. All costs associated therewith shall accrue to the person or persons responsible, including
