12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 320/714
SMALL TREES: Those attaining a height of twenty feet (20') to thirty feet (30').
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width of every public way or right of way when any part thereof is
open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic. (Ord.
804, 3-13-1978; amd. 1983 Code)
7-2-3: VILLAGE FORESTER:
A. Appointment And Qualifications: Upon satisfactory completion of a six (6) month probationary period,
that person shall hold office as long as he or she satisfactorily performs the duties of his or her office.
Preferably, that person will be one skilled and trained in the arts and sciences of municipal
arboriculture, and shall preferably hold a college degree or its equivalent in arboriculture, ornamental
or landscape horticulture, urban forestry or other closely related field.
B. Salary: The village forester shall receive a salary and fees as established by the village board of
trustees. The village shall reserve the right to assess any person to the full amount of the services
provided by the village forester.
C. Duties: The village forester shall have the authority to promulgate the rules and regulations of the
arboricultural specifications and standards of practice governing the planting, maintenance, removal,
fertilization, pruning and bracing of trees on the streets or other public sites in the village, and shall
direct, regulate and control the planting, maintenance and removal of all trees growing now or
hereafter in any public area of the village. He shall cause the provisions of this chapter to be
enforced. In his absence, these duties shall be the responsibility of a qualified alternate designated by
the village.
1. Planting And Maintenance: The village forester shall have the authority and jurisdiction of
regulating the planting, maintenance and removal of trees on streets and other publicly owned
property to ensure safety or preserve the aesthetics of such public sites.
2. Supervision: The village forester shall have the authority and it shall be his duty to supervise or
inspect all work done under a permit issued in accordance with the terms of this chapter.
3. Condition Of Permit: The village forester shall have the authority to affix reasonable conditions to
the granting of a permit in accordance with the terms of this chapter.
4. Master Street Plan: The village forester shall have the authority to formulate a master street tree
plan. The master street tree plan shall specify the species of tree to be planted on each of the
streets or other public sites of the village. From and after the effective date of the master street tree
plan, or any amendment thereof, all planting shall conform thereto.
a. The village forester shall consider all existing and future utility and environmental factors when
recommending a specific species for each of the streets and other public sites of the village.
b. The village forester shall have the authority to amend or add to the master street tree plan at any
time that circumstances make it advisable. (Ord. 804, 3-13-1978)
7-2-4: PERMITS REQUIRED:
A. Planting, Maintenance Or Removal:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 321/714
1. Permit Required: No person shall plant, spray, fertilize, preserve, prune, remove, cut aboveground
or otherwise disturb any tree on any street or village owned property without first filing an
application and procuring a permit from the village forester or otherwise specified municipal
authority. The person receiving the permit shall abide by the arboricultural specifications and
standards of practice adopted by the village forester.
2. Advance Application Required: Application for permits must be made at the office of the village
clerk not less than forty eight (48) hours in advance of the time the work is to be done.
3. Standards Of Issuance: The village forester shall issue the permit provided for herein if, in his
judgment, the proposed work is desirable and the proposed method and workmanship thereof are
of a satisfactory nature. Any permit granted shall contain a definite date of expiration and the work
shall be completed in the time allowed on the permit and in the manner as therein described. Any
permit shall be void if its terms are violated.
4. Notice Of Completion: Notice of completion shall be given within five (5) days to the village forester
for his inspection.
B. Planting:
1. Application On Data: The application required herein shall state the number of trees to be set out;
the location, grade, species, cultivar or variety of each tree; the method of planting; and such other
information as the village forester shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether
a permit should be issued.
2. Improper Planting: Whenever any tree shall be planted or set out in conflict with the provisions of
this section, it shall be lawful for the village forester to remove or cause removal of the same, and
the exact cost thereof shall be assessed to the owner as provided by law in the case of special
assessments.
C. Maintenance: The application required herein shall state the number and kinds of trees to be sprayed,
fertilized, pruned or otherwise preserved; the kind of treatment to be administered; the composition of
the spray material to be applied; and such other information as the village forester shall find
reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued.
D. Removal, Replanting And Replacement:
1. Wherever it is necessary to remove a tree or trees from a parkway in connection with the paving of
a sidewalk, or the paving or widening of the portion of a street or highway used for vehicular traffic,
the municipality shall replant such trees or replace them. Provided that conditions prevent planting
on parkways, this requirement will be satisfied if any equivalent number of trees of the same size
and species as provided for in the arboricultural specifications are planted in an attractive manner
on the adjoining property.
2. No person or property owner shall remove a tree from the parkway for the purpose of construction,
or for any other reason without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the village
forester, and without replacing the removed tree or trees in accordance with the adopted
arboricultural specifications. Such replacement shall meet the standards of size, species and
placement as provided for in a permit issued by the village forester. The person or property owner
shall bear the cost of removal and replacement of all trees removed. (Ord. 804, 3-13-1978)
7-2-5: PRUNING TREES:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 322/714
It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying real property bordering on any street
upon which property there may be trees or shrubs, to prune such trees or shrubs in such manner that
they will not obstruct or shade the streetlights, obstruct the passage of pedestrians on sidewalks, obstruct
vision of traffic signs, or obstruct view of any street or alley intersection, or obstruct utility lines. The
minimum clearance of any overhanging portion thereof shall be ten feet (10') over sidewalks and twelve
feet (12') over all streets except truck thoroughfares which shall have a clearance of sixteen feet (16').
A. Notice To Prune: Should any person owning real property bordering on any street fail to prune trees as
hereinabove provided, the village forester shall order such person or persons, within three (3) days
after receipt of written notice, to so prune such trees.
B. Order Required: The order required herein shall be served by mailing a copy of the order to the last
known address of the property owner, by certified mail.
C. Failure To Comply: When a person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply within the
specified time, it shall be lawful for the village to prune such trees, and the exact cost thereof shall be
assessed to the owner as provided by law. (Ord. 804, 3-13-1978)
7-2-6: PROTECTION OF TREES:
All trees on any street or other publicly owned property near any excavation or construction of any
building, structure or street work shall be guarded with a good substantial fence, frame or box not less
than four feet (4') high and eight feet (8') square, or at a distance in feet from the tree equal to the
diameter of the trunk in inches diameter breast height, whichever is greater, and all building materials,
dirt or other debris shall be kept outside the barrier. No person, except franchised public utilities, shall
excavate any ditches, tunnels, trenches or lay any drive within a radius of ten feet (10') from any public
tree without first obtaining a written permit from the village forester. (Ord. 804, 3-13-1978)
7-2-7: PROHIBITED ACTS OR CONDITIONS:
A. Abuse Or Mutilation Of Public Trees: Unless specifically authorized by the village forester, no person
shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, transport or remove any tree; attach any rope, wire, nails,
advertising posters, or other contrivance to any tree, allow any gaseous liquid or solid substance
which is harmful to such trees to come in contact with them; or set fire or permit any fire to burn when
such fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree.
B. Interference With Village Forester: No person shall hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the village
forester or any of his assistants while engaged in carrying out the execution or enforcement of this
chapter; provided however, that nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit the pursuit
of any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction for the protection of property
rights by the owner of any property within the village.
C. Placing Materials On Public Property: No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any
public place of the village any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other materials which may impede the
free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any tree growing therein, except by written
permit of the village forester. (Ord. 804, 3-13-1978)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 323/714
7-2-8: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a class
C misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined a sum no less than five dollars ($5.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or may be imprisoned for a term not exceeding thirty (30) days.
(Ord. 804, 3-13-1978; amd. 1983 Code)
Chapter 3
MUNICIPAL WATER AND SEWER
ARTICLE A. WATER USE AND SERVICE
7-3A-1: WATER USE PERMITS:
A. No water from the village water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person
but the superintendent of public works, or some person authorized by him to perform this service.
B. There shall be three (3) classes of building water permits:
For residential service.
For commercial service/industrial service.
For service to establishments producing industrial waste.
In any case the owner or his agent shall make application for service to the superintendent of public
works on a special form furnished by the village. The permit applications shall be supplemented by
any plans, specifications and/or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the
superintendent of public works. Permit and inspection fees are established in article D of this chapter
and shall be paid to the village clerk at the time the application is filed. No building permit shall be
issued until all applicable fees and deposits have been paid in full. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
C. For the purpose of maintaining adequate water levels in (privately owned) quasi-public storm water
retention ponds or decorative waterfalls, irrigation wells may be drilled within the corporate limits of
the village (in accordance with subsections D through G of this section).
D. Wells that are drilled for the purposes of irrigating (privately owned) quasi-public storm water retention
ponds or decorative waterfalls or other amenities that may be required through the development
agreement for increased landscaping features will be reviewed on a case by case basis and may not
be connected in any way to the village's potable water system. All costs for the installation and
maintenance of said wells will be the responsibility of the individual or entity requesting same.
E. Application for said water wells must be made to the village of Mokena public works department and
must include all pump design and performance standards for said well. Appropriate permits for the
installation of said wells must be obtained from the village of Mokena community development
department. These permits may include provisions for new electric service installations specifically
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 324/714
required to supply power to said wells. No construction of said proposed wells are allowed prior to the
issuance of said permit.
F. In addition to the village of Mokena permitting process the applicant or their agent must obtain permits
from the appropriate agency governing the installation of water wells in the state of Illinois, county of
Will.
G. Irrigation wells for the purpose of recharging retention ponds shall be designed to have a maximum
pump capacity of twenty (20) gallons per minute. Wells in excess of this standard will be reviewed on
a case by case basis and must be approved specifically by the public works director. (Ord. 2006-O-
021, 5-8-2006)
7-3A-2: INELIGIBILITY AND UNAUTHORIZED TURN ON:
A. Ineligibility For Water Service: No individual, contractor or corporation shall be eligible to have water
turned on for any use whatsoever, if that individual or corporation, at any time of application, has any
outstanding indebtedness for past water use.
B. Unauthorized Turn On: It shall be unlawful for any person to turn on the supply of water to any
premises from which it has been turned off by the village on account of nonpayment of outstanding
indebtedness or for any other reason, without having obtained a permit to do so from the
superintendent of public works. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-3: SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
A. General Requirements: No connections with a water main shall be made without a permit having been
issued by the village clerk and twenty four (24) hours' notice having been given to the superintendent
of public works. All such connections shall be made and all such work done at the expense of the
applicant or property owner who shall also furnish materials necessary for such work. All such
connections shall only be made by a licensed plumber with a performance bond currently in force and
properly executed in favor of the village, and the village shall be indemnified by such plumber and/or
the property owner from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be caused by such
installation. All such connections shall be inspected by the superintendent of public works or his
authorized agent and no connection shall be covered until the work has been inspected by him and
found to be satisfactory. When such work has been approved, the trench or excavation shall be
immediately refilled with suitable material and properly compacted to prevent settling and the flagging
and sidewalk restored to as good a condition as previous to the excavation. Applications for such
connections are subject to the standard fee for each connection.
B. Street Openings: The provisions of this code relating to excavations in streets1 shall be complied with
in making excavations in streets or other public places for water service connections. (Ord. 1294, 4-
13-1992)
C. Plumbing: No water shall be turned on for service in any premises in which the plumbing does not
comply with the provisions of the plumbing regulations of the Illinois state plumbing code as adopted
by the village of Mokena; provided, that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished
buildings subject to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2015-O-024, 9-14-2015)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 325/714
D. Municipal Water System: Any building erected within the corporate limits of the village of Mokena,
subsequent to the adoption date hereof, with a plumbing system and intended for human habitation or
occupancy located on premises adjacent to, abutting, contiguous, or within one hundred feet (100') of
a municipal water line shall have a connection made to the municipal water system.
E. Private Wells: No connections to the municipal water supply shall be allowed to any property that has
an active private well subsequent to the adoption date hereof. Should a property owner apply for a
connection to the municipal water supply, all private wells of the applicant on the property pertaining
to the application shall be capped, filled, disconnected from the system and permanently abandoned
from use prior to connecting to the municipal supply. (Ord. 2002-O-044, 11-25-2002)
7-3A-4: INSPECTIONS; RIGHT OF ENTRY:
Consumers of water shall, at all reasonable hours, permit authorized village officials to enter upon and
into their premises for the purpose of reading, inspecting, testing and/or replacement of meters and other
fixtures relating to the supply, control of supply and measurement of water consumption. (Ord. 1294, 4-
13-1992)
7-3A-5: WATER USE RESTRICTIONS:
A. The village of Mokena purchases Lake Michigan water from the village of Oak Lawn. Subject to the
three (3) tier emergency restrictions set forth below, in order for the village of Mokena to comply with
the Illinois department of transportation's "Rules And Regulations For The Allocation Of Water From
Lake Michigan" dated January 1985, as amended November 3, 1988, commencing from May 15
through September 15 of each year, it shall be unlawful for any person to use water for the sprinkling
or irrigation of lawns or gardens, except on an odd/even basis only (on odd numbered calendar days
if the last digit in the street address is odd and on even numbered days if the last digit in the street
address is even) between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. or
seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. (Ord. 2002-O-045, 11-25-2002; amd. Ord.
2008-O-024, 6-9-2008)
Under emergency conditions, as determined by the Oak Lawn president or the Oak Lawn president
and board of trustees based on the recommendation of Oak Lawn's director of public works relative to
the operational capacity of its water distribution system, the demands placed on the system by the
users and the risk of damage to or failure of the system, it shall be unlawful for any person to use
water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens, except during the permitted days and hours
set forth below: (Ord. 2002-O-045, 11-25-2002)
1. Tier 1 (Conservation Emergency): Sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens shall be permitted on
an odd/even basis between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.
only.
2. Tier 2 (Conservation Emergency): Sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens shall be permitted
Monday and Tuesday only on an odd/even basis between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. or seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
3. Tier 3 (Total Ban): Sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens and all outdoor watering is prohibited.
(Ord. 2008-O-024, 6-9-2008)
The Oak Lawn president or the Oak Lawn president and the board of trustees, or their designees,
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 326/714
shall provide notice by telephone, facsimile transmission, e-mail, United States mail, messenger
delivery or personal service to the president or the manager or administrator of the village of
Mokena, or one of their designees, whenever the tier 1, tier 2, or tier 3 restrictions are in effect; the
notice shall specify the type of tier emergency restriction and the duration of such restriction. Upon
receipt of notice that such an emergency restriction is in effect, the board of trustees or the village
president of Mokena, or their designee, shall provide notice in accordance with subsection C of this
section of the necessity to limit or suspend the use of water within the village of Mokena for the
sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special purpose(s) under this code.
(Ord. 2002-O-045, 11-25-2002; amd. Ord. 2008-O-024, 6-9-2008)
B. The village of Mokena reserves the right to further limit the use of water for the sprinkling or irrigation
of lawns and gardens or for any other special purposes whenever the president and board of trustees
of the village of Mokena shall determine that the public exigencies require such action. If public
exigencies so require, the president of the village of Mokena may unilaterally take such action prior to
the earliest opportunity available for consultation with the board of trustees.
C. Whenever the president or the president and board of trustees of the village of Mokena limit or
suspend the use of water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special
purpose(s), it shall be unlawful for any person, to use water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and
gardens or for any other special purpose(s) designated, other than during the times allowed for such
use(s) of water, or they have permission from the village of Mokena for the sprinkling of a new lawn.
The village shall post notice of the water use restriction, including the type and duration of such
restriction, within the customary posting place(s) in the village hall, on the village's cable access
television channel, its website and in any other medium normally used by the village to communicate
information of public concern to the residents and public. (Ord. 2002-O-045, 11-25-2002)
D. In the event that new sod or seed has been installed residents may obtain a permit from the building
department which will allow them to water on both odd and even days between the hours of seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. and/or seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. for twenty eight (28) days after the date of installation of the new sod or seed.
After the twenty eight (28) day period, normal odd/even sprinkling rules will apply.
E. In addition to the above restrictions, newly installed lawn sprinkling systems shall be equipped with an
approved rain detection device at installation. Permits for sprinkling system installation may be
obtained from the building department at which time a rain detection device can be approved and an
inspection of the installed system can be arranged. (Ord. 2004-O-016, 5-10-2004)
F. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2002-O-
045, 11-25-2002; amd. Ord. 2004-O-016, 5-10-2004)
7-3A-6: PROHIBITED ACTS OR CONDITIONS:
A. Resale Of Water: No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the village
supply to any premises other than that for which application has been made and the meter installed,
except in the case of a bona fide emergency.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 327/714
B. Tampering: It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the village to tamper with, alter or
injure any part of the village waterworks or supply system, or any meter.
C. Obstruction: It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct in any manner whatsoever the access to
any stopcock, shutoff valve (buffalo box), hydrant or valve connected with any water pipe, or to park
any automobile or vehicle within ten feet (10') of any hydrant. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
D. Water Wells: No water well shall be constructed, drilled, sunk or otherwise provided for in any manner
or on any parcel of land within the corporate limits of the village (for the purpose of potable water use)
which is currently connected to or may be served by the village water system (as referenced in
subsection 8-2-6B of this code). (Ord. 2006-O-021, 5-8-2006)
E. Distribution Of Well Water: Any well in use and operable at the time of adoption hereof within the
corporate limits of the village may only be used for and on the property that the well is located. Resale
of the water from the well or distribution of the water from the well to other properties is prohibited.
(Ord. 2002-O-044, 11-25-2002)
7-3A-7: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
7-3A-7-1: CORPORATION STOPCOCK:
Connection to any water main or water supply system of the village can only be made with a brass or
bronze Clow or Mueller corporation stopcock. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-7-2: SHUTOFF BOXES:
A. A shutoff box or service box (commonly called a buffalo box) shall be placed on every meter service
entrance pipe and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk or shall be five feet (5')
before the property line in the village parkway area in direct line with the connection to the main
where this is practicable, or in such other location as designated by either the village engineer or the
superintendent of public works. The shutoff box shall be of the saddle type with a twenty four inch
(24") extension rod. Such boxes shall be located so that they are easily accessible and shall be
protected from frost. If a water connection has been previously installed without a shutoff box, the
water user or property owner of such property shall install said shutoff box within thirty (30) days after
the date of notice from the superintendent of public works so demanding. Notice shall be sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested, and the date of mailing of such notice shall be deemed to be
the date of such notice. In the event the property owner shall fail to install a shutoff box within the time
allotted, such shutoff box will be installed by the village for the cost of installation, plus a service fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged for the use of water and services supplied by the village
and shall be included in, added to and become part of the regular water charge and shall be billed on
the next water bill rendered immediately following the date installation is begun or any water bill
subsequent thereto. When added to said bill, the installation charge and/or service fee shall be a part
of the regular rates and charges for water service and subject to all provisions of this chapter
concerning collection of delinquent charges, penalties thereof, liens and shutoff of service therefor.
B. At the time of application for turning on water service, the applicant and/or property owner shall
provide the village a scale or schematic drawing showing the location of the shutoff box (buffalo box)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 328/714
in reference to the property lines of the property concerned and identifying such property. The
applicant may be excluded from this requirement in the event that a shutoff box location drawing is
already on file with the department of public works. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-7-3: WATER LINES:
Building water service lines shall be constructed of type K soft copper tubing or ductile cast iron pipe of
the size and strength determined by the plumbing provisions adopted by the village and inspected by the
superintendent of public works or his authorized agent. All water lines shall be not less than five feet (5')
underground and protected from frost. No water service shall be provided by less than one inch (1")
diameter pipe. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-7-4: OLD WATER LINES:
Old building water lines may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on
examination and tested by the superintendent of public works or his authorized agent, to meet all
requirements and specifications of this chapter. All lead and galvanized water service lines shall be
replaced. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-7-5: SEPARATE LINES:
A separate and independent building water line shall be provided for every building, except where one
building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private line is available or can be
constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard or driveway. The building water line
from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building
line. Responsibility for the line from the village water main to the front building shall remain with the
owner of the front property and responsibility for the rear building line shall start at the point where the
line is connected to the front line and shall run to the rear building. At the point of connection two (2)
shutoff boxes (buffalo boxes) shall be installed governing supply of water to both buildings. (Ord. 1294, 4-
13-1992)
7-3A-7-6: REPAIRS:
All repairs for service pipes, corporation cocks, shutoff boxes (buffalo boxes), appliances or apparatus on
public property or on private premises and the plumbing systems of buildings which are defective or out
of good working order shall be repaired by and at the expense of the water user and/or the property
owner. If in the judgment of the superintendent of public works or his authorized agent said repairs are
necessary in the best interests of the village or are necessary for proper conservation of water, the water
user and/or the property owner shall be notified by certified mail by the village clerk demanding such
repairs and establishing the date by which they will be done. The village may, in case of emergency,
repair any service pipes or valves and if this is done, the cost of such repair work plus a service fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged the user and/or owner of the premises and shall be
considered a part of the water bill subject to all provisions thereof and shall be repaid to the village by the
water user and/or the property owner of the premises. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-7-7: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 329/714
All connections to the water system of the village, whether within or without the village, shall be subject to
the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-8: METERS:
All premises using the village water supply must be equipped with an approved type water meter with
outside meter in good operating condition. All new meters being placed in service shall be Neptune water
meters furnished by the village but paid for by the consumer and/or property owner. Applications for
water meters shall be placed with the village clerk, and after receiving a deposit of an amount equal to
the cost of said meter, plus an additional thirty percent (30%) thereof, the meter shall thereafter be
maintained by the village. After application has been filed with the village clerk, interim water service may
be supplied by the village at an average usage rate until such meter may be installed, except as provided
for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this chapter. These conditions
will be satisfied or no water shall be furnished to the premises. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-8-1: METER CONNECTIONS:
All meters shall be connected with standard brass unions and sealed. A properly sized ball valve shall be
provided on either side of the meter installation. No person, unless authorized by the superintendent of
public works, shall connect, disconnect, remove, repair, or otherwise disturb any water meter. (Ord. 2015-
O-024, 9-14-2015)
7-3A-8-2: METER LOCATIONS:
All meters shall be installed in a location that will be ready and have easy access for routine meter
reading and/or service or replacement. All existing installations which do not comply with these
provisions shall be changed at the property owner's or water user's expense within thirty (30) days after
the date of notice from the superintendent of public works or his authorized agent demanding such
change. A one-half inch (1/2") conduit, complete with pull wire shall be installed between the water meter
and the outside remote readout. Unless approved by the superintendent of public works, the remote
readout must be securely fastened to a side of the building at a point readily accessible to the meter
reader and no less than four feet (4') above the finished grade. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-8-3: METER SIZE:
The size and/or capacity of the water meter to be installed will depend on the volume of water
consumption and other factors deemed pertinent by the superintendent of public works or his authorized
agent. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-8-4: REPAIRS AND REPLACEMENT OF METERS:
The village shall be responsible for repairs and replacement of water meters. A meter will be considered
out of repair when it is underregistering to an extent of at least three percent (3%) or when it is found, in
the opinion of the superintendent of public works, to be inoperative or not operating properly, then such a
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 330/714
meter shall be replaced with a new or replacement meter. Such determination shall be made by the
superintendent and shall be conclusive. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-8-5: METER TESTING:
In case of a dispute over the amount of a water bill or over the accuracy of a meter, and upon application
made to the superintendent of public works for any meter test, the village shall test the meter for a fee.
The fee shall be as follows:
Fiscal year 2015 $73.00
If it is found upon such a test that the meter registers a greater amount of water than has actually passed
through it, the bill will be adjusted to conform to the correct amount passing through the meter and the
testing fee will be refunded, and the meter repaired or replaced with another meter that registers within
three percent (3%) of the actual flow through it. If, however, the meter registers a less amount than
actually passed through it in the test, the applicant for such test shall be required to pay on the basis of
the correct amount of water passing through the meter and the meter will be repaired or replaced as set
forth above. The village may test any water meter for accuracy at any reasonable time. (Ord. 2014-O-
026, 6-23-2014)
7-3A-8-6: USE OF METERS IN MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS:
No village water shall be furnished to individual apartment units in a multi-family residential building
unless it is first measured through a master meter measuring the water furnished to all individual
apartment units in that multi-family residential building. In multi-family buildings in which the units are
under different ownership, facilities must be provided to measure individual water usage to each unit.
Village water furnished to individual apartments may be measured through individual meters, if either of
such individual meters is registered in the name of the owner of the multi-family residential building and
he executes a written agreement with the village to act as surety for the water account of each individual
apartment unit in his name. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-8-7: BREAKING SEAL OF WATER METER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to break, or cause to be broken, the seal on any water meter, unless
authorized to do so by the superintendent of public works, or his authorized agent. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-
1992)
7-3A-8-8: UNAUTHORIZED TAMPERING WITH METERS:
The owner of the building, structure or premises for which a water meter is installed, or the person in
possession, charge or control thereof shall be held responsible for any unauthorized tampering or
interference with such water meter, and the water supply to such building or premises shall be cut off and
shall not again be turned on until person or property owner shall have paid the village the standard fee
for cutting off water service and the standard fee for turning on such service; provided, that such person
or property owner can show that such tampering was done contrary to his efforts to prevent same, there
shall be no cutting off of the water supply. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 331/714
7-3A-9: DEDUCT METERS:
A. Any person wishing to install a water deduct meter shall make application to the superintendent of
public works on a special form furnished by the village. This meter shall measure the amount of water
which is not discharged into the sanitary sewer. The measured amount of water not discharged into
the sanitary sewer shall be deducted from the total amount measured by the primary water meter and
billed at a rate as set by ordinance in the corresponding monthly billing period. (Ord. 1335, 3-8-1993)
B. Deduct meters shall only be permitted for use on property zoned E-1, and R-1 through R-5, and may
be issued to individually owned units in townhome developments zoned R-6. Deduct meters may also
be issued to homeowner associations for use in conjunction with common areas of property zoned R-
6. These common area deduct meters for property zoned R-6 must be located in an outside
underground meter vault and shall be used solely for the purpose of supplying water to an approved
underground sprinkling system. The maximum size water tap for such sprinkling system shall be two
inches (2") in diameter and the fee for said tap shall be the current rate for residential use. (Ord. 1441,
4-24-1995)
7-3A-9-1: DEDUCT METER CONNECTIONS:
Water deduct meters shall be installed on interior water lines supplying outside hose bibs or lawn
irrigation systems only. Water deduct meters shall not be connected to any permanent or temporary
water piping system that terminates or has potential to terminate at an interior water outlet. (Ord. 1294, 4-
13-1992)
7-3A-9-2: DEDUCT METER COSTS:
The applicant shall pay a deposit equal to the cost of the water deduct meter plus an additional thirty
percent (30%). In addition, the applicant shall pay to the village an inspection and sealing fee as
periodically set by the village. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-9-3: DEDUCT METER INSTALLATION:
It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to arrange for the installation of the deduct meter. Deduct
meters shall be installed by a plumbing contractor licensed in the state of Illinois and currently licensed
by the village. Deduct meter installations shall comply with all of the regulations and provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-9-4: DEDUCT METER INSPECTION:
The applicant shall notify the village upon completion of the installation and request an inspection of
same. Upon approval by the plumbing inspector or representative of the public works department, the
deduct meter will be sealed and put into service. The village retains the right to gain access to the
property to inspect and test any water meter assembly for compliance with these regulations. (Ord. 1294,
4-13-1992)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 332/714
7-3A-9-5: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
In addition to any other applicable penalties contained within this code, a violation of this article will result
in nullification of the deduct meter readings and removal of the deduct meter at owner's expense. (Ord.
1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-10: LIABILITY OF WATER USERS:
A copy of this article, properly certified by the village clerk, shall be filed in the office of the recorder of
deeds of Will County, Illinois, and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of their liability for
water service supplied to an occupant or user of such service on their properties, including cost of
installation and proper maintenance of same. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
7-3A-11: WATER SUPPLY STANDARDS ADOPTED:
The Mokena fire protection district ordinance 3-9-80, entitled "an ordinance establishing minimum
standards for water supply, water mains and fire hydrants", as adopted and approved on September 9,
1980, by the president and board of trustees of the Mokena fire protection district, Will County and Cook
County, Illinois, three (3) certified copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk and made a
part of this section by reference thereto, be and is hereby adopted and enacted as an ordinance of the
village. (Ord. 1294, 4-13-1992)
ARTICLE B. SEWER USE AND SERVICE
7-3B-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as
follows:
ACT OR FEDERAL ACT: The federal water pollution control act, as amended, public law 92-500, 33 USC
1251 et seq.
ADMINISTRATOR: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
AUTHORITY: The village of Mokena.
BOD (Denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical
oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five (5) days at twenty degrees
Celsius (20°C), expressed in parts per million by weight.
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which received the
discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the
building sewer, beginning five feet (5') outside the inner face of the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal.
CLERK OR VILLAGE CLERK: The clerk of the village of Mokena.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 333/714
COMBINED SEWERS: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage.
CONTROL MANHOLE: A structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where
feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to provide access
for the village representative to sample and/or measure discharges.
DIRECTOR (IEPA): Director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
DISSOLVED SOLIDS: That concentration of matter in the sewage consisting of colloidal particulate
matter one micron in diameter or less, and both organic and inorganic molecules and ions present in
solution.
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
FECAL COLIFORM: Any number of organisms common to the intestinal tract of man and animals whose
presence in sanitary sewage is an indicator of pollution.
FLOATABLE OIL: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from
wastewater by treatment in a pretreatment facility approved by the authority.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling,
storage and sale of produce.
IEPA: Illinois environmental protection agency.
INCOMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Any nontreatable waste product including nonbiodegradable dissolved
solids.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The liquid wastes from the industrial processes as distinguished from sanitary
sewage.
INFILTRATION: The water unintentionally entering the public sewer system, including sanitary building
drains and sewers, from the ground, through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe
joints, connections, or manhole walls. (Infiltration does not include and is distinguished from inflow).
INFILTRATION/INFLOW: The total quantity of water from both infiltration and inflow without distinguishing
the source.
INFLOW: The water discharge into a sanitary sewer system, including building drains and sewers, from
such sources as, but not limited to, roof leaders, cellar, yard, and area drains, foundation drains,
unpolluted cooling water discharges, drains from springs and swampy areas, manhole covers, cross
connections from storm sewers and/or combined sewers, catch basins, storm waters, surface runoff,
street wash waters or drainage. (Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from, infiltration).
INSPECTOR: The person or persons duly authorized by the village, through the board of trustees, to
inspect and approve the installation of building sewers and their connection to the public sewer system.
INTERCEPTOR SEWER: A sewer whose primary purpose is to transport wastewater from collection
sewers to a treatment facility.
MAJOR COMBINING INDUSTRY: An industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: a) has a
flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average work day; or b) has a flow greater than ten
percent (10%) of the flow carried by a municipal system receiving the waste; or c) has in its waste, a toxic
pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section 307(a) of the federal act; or d) is
found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 334/714
publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in
combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from
that treatment works.
NPDES PERMIT: Any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the administrator, or,
where appropriated by the director, after enactment of the federal clean water act to regulate the
discharge of pollutants pursuant to section 402 of the federal act. The logarithm of the reciprocal of
weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or body of surface or ground water.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group.
PRETREATMENT: The treatment of industrial sewage from privately owned industrial sources prior to
introduction of the waste effluent into a public treatment works, in accordance with 40 CFR 128.
PRIVATE SEWER: A sewer which is not owned by the village of Mokena.
PROPERLY SHREDDED: Waste from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been
shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally
prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and controlled by
public authority.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm surface and groundwater are not
intentionally admitted.
SEWAGE: A combination of the water carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions,
and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and storm waters as may be present.
SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANT: Arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage.
SEWAGE WORKS: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage.
SEWER: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage.
SHALL, MAY: Shall is mandatory; may is permissive.
SIGNIFICANT INDUSTRY: Any industry that will contribute greater than ten percent (10%) of the design
flow and/or design pollutant loading of the treatment works.
SLUG: Any discharge of water or wastewater which is concentration of any given constituent or in any
quantity of flow which exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five
(5) times the average twenty four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal operation and shall
adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works.
STANDARD METHODS: The laboratory procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis,
of "Standard Methods For The Examination Of Water And Wastewater" prepared and published jointly by
the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution
Control Federation and 40 CFR part 136, 3, 4, and 5, and/or other recognized procedures by USEPA and
IEPA.
STORM SEWER OR STORM DRAIN: A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but
excludes sewage and polluted industrial waste.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 335/714
SUPERINTENDENT: The superintendent of public works of the combined municipal water and sewer
department of the village, or his authorized deputy, agent or representative.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or
other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering.
TOXIC AMOUNT: Concentration of any pollutant or combination of pollutants which upon exposure to or
assimilation into any organism will cause adverse effects, such as cancer, genetic mutations and
physiological manifestations, as defined in standards issued pursuant to section 307(a) of PL 92-500.
USEPA: United States environmental protection agency.
UNPOLLUTED WATER: Water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect, or water that
would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to
the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
WATERCOURSE: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continually or intermittently. (Ord.
1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-2: INSTALLATION REQUIRED:
The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or
other purposes situated within the village and abutting any street, alley or right of way in which there is
now located or may in the future be located a public sewer or combined sewer of the village, is hereby
required at his own expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities with
the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter within thirty (30) days after the
date of official notice to do so; provided that said public sewer is within one hundred feet (100') of the
property line.
At such time as public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal
system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this chapter within thirty
(30) days after official notice to do so, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage
disposal facilities shall be filled with sand or crushed stone and shall be abandoned. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-
1991)
7-3B-3: PRIVATE SYSTEMS:
A. General: Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available, the building sewer shall be
connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with all recommendations of the Will
County health department. All private sewage disposal facilities shall be maintained in a sanitary
manner at all times, at no expense to the village.
B. Privies Or Septic Tanks: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain
any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facilities intended or used for the disposal of
sewage.
C. Application, Permit: Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system the
owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the village clerk. The application for such permit
shall be made on a form furnished by the village, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans,
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 336/714
specifications, and other information as are deemed necessary by the village clerk. A permit and
inspection fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid to the village at the time the application is
filed.
D. Inspection: A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the
installation is completed to the satisfaction of the village. The village shall be allowed to inspect the
work at any stage of construction and the applicant shall notify the village in writing within seventy two
(72) hours of final inspection.
E. Compliance: The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall
comply with all recommendations of the state of Illinois private sewage disposal licensing act and
code and with the state of Illinois environmental protection agency. No permit shall be issued for any
facilities where the area of the lot is less than forty thousand (40,000) square feet. No septic tank or
cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-4: SEWER PERMITS:
A. Classes: There shall be three (3) classes of building sewer permits:
For residential service.
For commercial/industrial service.
For service to establishments producing industrial wastes.
In any case the owner or his agent shall make application for service to the superintendent of public
works on a special form furnished by the village. The permit application shall be supplemented by any
plans, specifications and/or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the
superintendent. Permit and inspection fees are established in article D of this chapter and shall be
paid to the village clerk at the time the application is filed. No building permit shall be issued until all
applicable fees and deposits have been paid in full.
B. Service Connections: No connections with a public sewer shall be made without a permit having been
issued by the village and twenty four (24) hours' notice having been given to the superintendent. All
such connections shall be made, and all such work done at the expense of the applicant and/or
property owner who shall also furnish materials necessary for such work. All such connections shall
only be made by a licensed plumber with a performance bond currently in force and properly
executed in favor of the village, and the village shall be indemnified by such plumber and/or the
property owner from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be caused by such installation.
All such connections shall be inspected by the superintendent or his agent and no connection shall be
covered until the work has been inspected and found to be satisfactory. When such work has been
approved, the trench or excavation shall be immediately refilled and the dirt tamped and the street,
flagging and sidewalk restored to as good condition as previous to excavation and pursuant to
chapter 1, article A of this title. Applications for such connections are subject to the standard fee for
each connection.
C. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to uncover or make any opening into, or connection with, or to
alter or disturb any public sewer without having first obtained a permit therefor. Applications for such
permits shall be made to the superintendent and shall be accompanied by a statement as to the
purpose of such connection, the premises to be served and the specification of such pipe to be
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 337/714
connected and the drain from the building to sewer pipe, together with a schematic or scale drawing
of reasonably permanent nature, eight and one-half inches by eleven inches (81/2" x 11") overall size,
showing the location of such sewer connection in relation to the property lines. Such application shall
be referred to the superintendent and no such permit shall be issued unless he shall have found that
all provisions of this code would be complied with by making such connection.
D. Reserve Capacity: A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be
allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump
stations, and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and
efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-5: CONDITIONS OF USE:
A. Cross Connections: No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface
water, ground water, roof runoffs, subsurface drainage, cooling waters or unpolluted industrial process
waters into any sanitary sewer.
B. Storm Water:
1. Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are
specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the
superintendent.
2. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or permit or cause to be discharged sanitary and
industrial waste water into any storm sewers or natural outlet.
3. It shall be unlawful to construct or permit the construction of any storm water drain which
discharges water onto any sidewalk in the village, and it shall be unlawful to construct or permit the
maintenance of any such drain which discharges into any public street or alley at a height greater
than eighteen inches (18") above the ground or pavement.
C. Industrial Cooling Water: Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged
upon approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural outlet. (Ord. 1253,
6-24-1991)
7-3B-6: BUILDING SEWER LINE CONNECTIONS:
Building service sewers shall generally enter the sewer main or lateral by way of an existing wye or tee. If
another method is desired, a detail shall be submitted for review, and approved by the superintendent
before the connection is made. It shall be unlawful for any person to break the sewer main pipe without
the express written consent of the superintendent. In the event of absence of the wye or tee, the
connection to the sewer main or lateral shall be made by one of the methods indicated as follows:
A. Installation of a manhole.
B. Circular saw cut or sewer main by proper tools ("Shewer-Tap" machine or similar), and proper
installation of hub wye saddle or hub tee saddle, in accordance with manufacturer's
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 338/714
recommendations.
C. Remove an entire section of pipe and replace with a wye or tee branch section. Pipe section shall be
removed by breaking only the top of one bell. After the wye or tee branch is inserted, concrete shall
be placed over the broken area to a minimum thickness of four inches (4") and to a dimension of eight
inches (8") in all directions.
D. Using pipe cutter, neatly and accurately cut out desired length of pipe for insertion of proper fitting.
Use "band-seal" couplings, or similar couplings, and shear rings and clamps to fasten the inserted
fitting and hold it firmly in place. Follow manufacturer's recommendations for the installation. (Ord.
1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-7: STREET OPENINGS:
The provisions of this code and the provisions of the remaining village codes and/or policies of the village
board relating to excavations in streets shall be complied with in making excavations in streets or other
public places for sewer and/or water connections. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-8: SEPARATE SEWERS REQUIRED:
A separate and independent sewer shall be provided for every building, except where one building
stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to
the rear building through an adjoining alley, court or driveway, the building sewer from the front building
may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. Responsibility for
the sewer from the village sewer line, including the connection thereto, to the front building shall remain
with the owner of the front property and responsibility for the rear building sewer shall start at the point of
connection to the front sewer and shall run to the rear building. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9: BUILDING SEWER SPECIFICATIONS:
The building sewer pipe shall meet or exceed one of the following types of materials and joint
construction:
Pipe Material Joint
Cast iron pipe ASA A21.6 ASA A21.10
ASA A21.11
Cast iron soil pipe ASA A74 ASTM C564
PVC sewer pipe ASTM D3034-'73 Ring
SDR 35
For jointing pipes of different materials including PVC sewer pipe to ABS sewer pipe, a "band-seal"
coupling is required. Other materials may be approved by the superintendent, provided such requests for
use of a different pipe material is made in writing not less than forty eight (48) hours prior to construction.
Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet (10') of a water service pipe shall meet the
requirements of ASA A21.6 with mechanical or compression type joints. If installed in uncompacted fill or
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 339/714
unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron pipe, except that nonmetallic material may be
accepted if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the inspector. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-
1991)
7-3B-9-1: PLUMBING:
The plumbing and fixtures installed in any building in the village must be installed to comply with the
plumbing provisions of the Illinois state plumbing code, which is hereby adopted as the standard of
specifications for plumbing. It shall be unlawful to install any plumbing or fixtures which do not comply
with the above regulations. The superintendent and the plumbing inspector shall keep on file in their
offices or usual places where their records are kept not less than three (3) copies of the current Illinois
state plumbing code, which shall be available for reference and inspection. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9-2: SIZE AND SLOPE:
The size and slope of the building sewers shall be subject to the approval of the said superintendent, but
in no event shall the diameter be less than six inches (6"), and the slope thereof shall not be less than
one-eighth inch (1/8") per foot. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9-3: SERVICE LATERAL LENGTH AND MANHOLES:
A. Single Residences: Where the service lateral extends one hundred feet (100') for a single-family
residence or a ninety degree (90°) bend is required to service the residence, manholes shall be
installed as directed by the village engineer or superintendent.
B. Multiple-Family Buildings: For multiple-family buildings with four (4) or less units, requirements shall be
the same as for single-family residences. For buildings of over four (4) units, the requirements for
manholes shall be as determined by the village engineer. For multiple-family buildings or complexes
(more than one building), containing sixteen (16) or more units, a manhole must be constructed for
connecting the proposed sewer lateral to the main sewer.
C. Commercial Or Industrial Buildings Or Developments: The village engineer shall designate the type of
sewer tap permitted and the requirements of manholes for industrial developments. For such
developments that will discharge other than domestic waste, an inspection manhole is required. (Ord.
1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9-4: RISER ASSEMBLIES:
Where the existing sewer is eight feet (8') or more in depth, riser assemblies may be used to a minimum
depth of not less than seven feet (7'). All bends required for riser construction shall be made with
appropriate fittings and elbows, except that elbows of greater than forty five degrees (45°) will not be
permitted. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9-5: MAINTENANCE:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 340/714
The maintenance of sanitary sewer laterals from the main or trunk sewer to the unit being served shall be
the responsibility of the owner of such unit. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9-6: SEWAGE LIFT:
In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary
sewage carried by such drains shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building
sewer. No water operated sewage ejector shall be used. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9-7: INFILTRATION:
A. Visible infiltration shall be prohibited.
B. Infiltration shall not exceed two (2) gallons per day per one hundred feet (100') of service lateral.
Where the village engineer feels conditions warrant it, an infiltration test shall be conducted on the
service lateral. Such tests shall be paid for by the property owner. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-9-8: EXISTING SEPTIC TANKS:
Where a new sewer service replaces a septic tank and seepage field system, the existing septic tank and
any existing manholes shall be filled with sand after existing sanitary wastes have been removed. The
connection of the new service lateral through an existing septic tank will not be permitted. (Ord. 1253, 6-
24-1991)
7-3B-9-9: OLD BUILDING SEWERS:
Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found on
examination and test by the superintendent to meet all requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-
1991)
7-3B-10: WASTE ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in an unsanitary manner
upon public or private property within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any
human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-11: DISCHARGE OF EFFLUENT:
It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the village, or in any area under the
jurisdiction of the village, any sanitary sewage, industrial waste, or other polluted waters, except where
suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with provisions of this article. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 341/714
7-3B-12: GARAGE DRAINS:
Floor drains in garages or filling stations shall be connected to a storm sewer system. Such drains shall
have intercepting mud or grease traps adequate to prevent the flow of mud or grease into the sewer
system. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-1991)
7-3B-13: INTERCEPTORS:
Grease, oil and sand or mud interceptors shall be provided on any sewer when, in the opinion of the
superintendent or the inspector, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing
grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, mud and other harmful ingredients, except
that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors
shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent and shall be located as to be readily and
easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of
impervious material capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature, and shall be of
substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in
place shall be gastight and watertight. Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be
maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. (Ord. 1253, 6-24-
1991)
7-3B-14: PROHIBITED SUBSTANCES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any gasoline, benzine or other volatile liquid to flow into any
public sewer in the village, or to permit any material which might injure any part of the sanitary sewer
system to flow into it. Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall discharge or cause to be
discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer:
A. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature high enough to create damaging or adverse effects on the
treatment process or to prevent compliance with IEPA regulations.
B. Any water or waste which may contain more than one hundred parts per million (100 ppm) by weight,
of fat, oil or grease.
C. Any water or waste which may contain more than twenty five parts per million (25 ppm), by weight, of
soluble oils.
D. Any gasoline, benzine, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas.
E. Any garbage that has not been properly shredded.
F. Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood,
paunch manure, or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in
sewers or their interference with the proper operation of the sewage works.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 342/714
G. Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.0 or higher than 9.0 or having any other corrosive
property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage
works.
H. Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or
interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any
hazard in the receiving waters to the sewage treatment plant.
I. Any waters or wastes containing BOD or suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual
attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage disposal plant.
J. Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance.
K. Any waters or wastes containing radioactive material or radioisotopes (giving off radiant energy in the
form of alpha, beta, or gamma rays) in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage
treatment process, constituting a hazard to humans or animals or creating any hazard in the receiving
waters of the sewage treatment plant.
L. Any amount of the following constituents exceeding that listed below:
