(4') in height above the average level of the adjoining ground.
THEATER: A building or part of a building devoted to showing motion pictures or for dramatic, dance,
musical, or other live performances.
THEATERS (OUTDOOR): An outdoor area used for dramatic, motion picture, or other performances.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 604/714
THROUGH LOT: A lot having its front and rear lot lines on adjacent and substantially parallel streets,
otherwise known as a double frontage lot.
TRADE CONTRACTOR: A building or portion thereof where building and construction trade services are
provided to the public. "Trade contractor" shall include, but will not be limited to, contractor offices,
including landscaper's showrooms, construction supplies and storage including plumbing, heating, air
conditioning, and building equipment, materials, sales, and other uses similar in nature and impact.
"Trade contractor" shall not include any use that is otherwise listed specifically in a zoning district as a
permitted or special use.
TRAILER: A vehicle without motive power used or adaptable for living, sleeping, business, or storage
purposes, having no foundation other than wheels, blocks, skids, jacks, horses, or skirting, and has been
recently or may be equipped with wheels or other devices for transporting the structure from place to
place. A permanent foundation shall not change its character unless the entire structure is erected in
accordance with the village building code.
TRELLIS: A latticed structure designed specifically for the purpose of supporting leafy vines. No structure
shall be considered as a trellis for the purposes of this title unless the plant material typically associated
with a trellis is in place.
TWENTY FOUR HOUR UNATTENDED BUSINESS WITH CONTROLLED ACCESS: A commercial
establishment, office, institutional, or industrial use which produces goods, or distributes goods and
services, that is not accessible to the general public, and in which customers are granted controlled
access at times when the business is unattended by an owner, manager, or designated employee.
UNIFIED CONTROL: The combination of two (2) or more tracts of land wherein each owner has agreed
that his tract of land shall be developed as part of a planned development and shall be subject to the
control applicable to the planned development.
UPPERMOST REACH: An open drainage channel intended to serve two (2) or more lots and generally
found on private property. It is the first level of common drainage system, and is generally used to convey
periodic rainfall to a storm sewer.
USE: The purpose or activity for which the land, or building thereon, is designed, arranged or intended,
or for which it is occupied or maintained, and shall include any manner of performance of such activity
with respect to the performance standards of this zoning ordinance.
USE, LAWFUL: The use of any structure or land that conforms with all of the regulations of this title or
any amendment hereto and which conforms with all of the codes, ordinances, and other legal
requirements, as existing at the time of the enactment of this title or any amendment thereto, for the
structure or land that is being examined.
USE, PRINCIPAL: The primary use of land or buildings as distinguished from a subordinate or accessory
use.
USE, SECONDARY PRINCIPAL: A use, subordinate to the primary use, that is established on a lot or
structure subsequent to or at the same time as the primary use but which is not accessory to the primary
use.
USE, TEMPORARY: A use that is established for a fixed period of time with the intent to discontinue such
use upon the expiration of such time.
VALUATION: For the purposes of this title, valuation of a building shall be the assessed valuation, or
where no assessed valuation exists, its appraised valuation as converted to assessed valuation.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 605/714
VEHICLE TOWING ESTABLISHMENTS: A building, property, or activity, the principal use of which is the
retrieving or securing of distressed, disabled, abandoned, or illegally parked motorized vehicles. "Vehicle
towing establishments" shall not include any use that is otherwise listed specifically in a zoning district as
a permitted or special use.
WAREHOUSE: A building or portion thereof used for the storage of goods and/or materials. This term
shall include, but not be limited to, industrial storage facilities, and other uses similar in nature and
impact.
WETLANDS: Areas defined by the army corps of engineers.
WHOLESALE GOODS ESTABLISHMENT: A building, property, or activity, the use or purpose of which is
the sale of goods, products, or merchandise, in bulk quantities to retailers or persons who will in turn sell
the goods, products or merchandise directly to the consumer. "Wholesale goods establishment" shall not
include any use or other type of establishment that is otherwise listed specifically on a zoning district as a
permitted or special use.
WIND TURBINES: An alternate energy device which converts wind energy by means of a rotor to
electrical energy.
WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE FACILITY: An unmanned facility consisting of antennas,
equipment, and equipment storage shelter used for the reception, switching, and/or transmission of
wireless telecommunications including, but not limited to, paging, enhanced specialized mobile radio,
personal communication services, cellular telephone, and similar technologies. A wireless
communication service facility may be either freestanding, roof mounted, or building mounted.
YARD: An open space on the same zoning lot with a principal building or group of buildings which is
unoccupied and unobstructed from its lowest level upward, except as otherwise permitted in this title, and
which extends along a lot line and at right angles thereto to a depth or width specified in the yard
regulations for the district in which the zoning lot is located.
YARD, FRONT: A yard extending across the full width of the zoning lot in accordance with the yard
provisions of this title.
YARD, REAR: A yard extending across the full width of the rear of the lot between the side yards.
YARD, SIDE: A yard extending along a side lot line from the front yard to the rear yard.
ZONING CERTIFICATE: A writing from the zoning official approving a use, operation, or activity.
ZONING MAP: The map or maps incorporated into this title as a part hereof, designating zoning districts.
ZONING OFFICIAL: The individual appointed by the President, by and with the consent of the Village
Board, to administer and enforce the zoning ordinance of the Village. (Ord. 2009-O-032, 8-10-2009; amd.
Ord. 2011-O-015, 8-8-2011; Ord. 2012-O-033, 12-10-2012; Ord. 2014-O-015, 4-28-2014; Ord. 2014-O-
032, 9-22-2014; Ord. 2017-O-013, 4-24-2017; Ord. 2018-O-013, 6-11-2018)
Title 10
LAND SUBDIVISIONS
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 606/714
Chapter 1
GENERAL SUBDIVISION PROVISIONS AND
IMPROVEMENTS
10-1-1: TITLE:
These regulations contained in this title shall be referred to officially as THE SUBDIVISION
REGULATIONS OF THE VILLAGE OF MOKENA, ILLINOIS; and the term "regulations" or "subdivision
regulations" when used in this title shall mean and shall have the force and effect of ordinance provisions
of the village. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-1-2: PURPOSE:
In order to promote the realization of the official plan of the village and contiguous territory; in order to
provide reasonable requirements for public streets, community facilities and other public grounds; in
order to provide for the health, safety, comfort and convenience of the residents of the village and
contiguous territory; the following regulations establishing reasonable standards of design and procedure
for subdivisions and for resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment within
the village and contiguous unincorporated territory are hereby adopted as part of the official map of the
village. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-1-3: AUTHORITY:
Authority for the administration of these regulations shall be vested in the planning commission and the
village board as hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-1-4: JURISDICTION:
These regulations shall be applicable to all subdivisions and resubdivisions of land within the corporate
limits of the village and contiguous unincorporated territory not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles
beyond the corporate limits of the village and not included in any other municipality. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-
1998)
10-1-5: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of these regulations, certain words and phrases used herein are defined as follows:
ALLEY: A minor public right of way used primarily for vehicular service access to the rear or side of
properties.
APPROVED STREET: Any street, whether public or private, meeting standards and specifications of the
village.
BUFFER PLANTING STRIP: A narrow area planted with trees and shrubs for screening purposes.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 607/714
BUILDING SETBACK: The line indicating the minimum horizontal distance between the property line and
building extremities, either at the front or side of the lot.
CONCEPT PLAN: A rough plan showing the land uses, road systems, densities, and other general
characteristics of a proposed development.
CONTIGUOUS TERRITORY: Unincorporated territory not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles
removed from the village limits and not included in any other municipality.
CROSSWALKWAY: A public right of way, ten feet (10') or more in width between property lines, which
provides pedestrian access to adjacent properties.
CUL-DE-SAC: A short street having one end open to traffic and being terminated at the other end by a
vehicular turnaround.
DESIGN ENGINEER: The individual or firm retained by the owner/developer who is responsible for the
design and preparation of construction documents for a project.
DEVELOPER: Any person, contract purchaser, or agent or contractor thereof, dividing or proposing to
divide land so as to constitute a "subdivision" as defined herein. Including any individual, group,
corporation or any combination thereof acting as a unit.
DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR: The individual who is responsible for the overall management and general
administration of the community development department, and his or her representatives and
subordinates.
EASEMENT: A grant by the owner of the use of a strip of land by others for specific purposes.
FINAL PLAT: The final map or drawing on which the subdivision plan is submitted to the village for
approval and which, if approved, will be submitted to the county clerk for recording.
FRONTAGE: All the property on one side of a street between two (2) intersecting streets (crossing or
terminating) measured along the center line of the street, or if the street is deadended, then all the
property abutting on one side between an intersecting street and the deadend street.
LOT: A portion of a subdivision intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for development.
OFFICIAL PLAN: The comprehensive plan or any portion thereof made and adopted by the board of
trustees in accordance with the laws of the state and the ordinances of the village indicating the general
or specific locations recommended for streets, parks, public buildings, zoning districts, and all other
public improvements.
PARKWAY: That area of a street right of way between the back of curb or pavement edge and the right of
way line.
PLANNING COMMISSION: The planning commission of the village.
PRELIMINARY LAYOUT OR PRELIMINARY PLAT: The preliminary map or drawing on which the
proposed layout of subdivision is submitted to the village for consideration and tentative approval.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS INSPECTOR: An individual, company or firm approved by the village to
observe construction for compliance with approved drawings and specifications.
RECORD DRAWINGS: Design drawings checked in the field and which are revised to show as12/
18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 608/714
constructed type, size and locations.
RIGHT OF WAY: A general term denoting land, property or interest therein, usually in a strip acquired for
or devoted to transportation purposes.
ROADWAY: The portion of a street available for vehicular traffic; where curbs are laid, the portion
between the curbs.
SIDEWALK: The portion of a street or crosswalkway, paved or otherwise surfaced, intended for
pedestrian use.
STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS: The most current edition of the "Standard Specifications For Road And
Bridge Construction" state of Illinois, department of transportation, which may be used in conjunction with
the village of Mokena's standard specifications for subdivision improvements.
STREET: A public right of way having the primary purpose of providing for vehicular and pedestrian
access to adjacent properties.
STREET, COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL: Those which act as feeders to commercial and industrial
districts from and between minor arterials and major collectors, serving as major traffic ways for heavy
traffic and truck traffic regardless of volume.
STREET, LOCAL: Those having limited continuity and carrying up to two thousand (2,000) vehicles per
day which are used primarily for access to abutting properties, or to meet the local traffic flow needs of a
neighborhood or community.
STREET, MAJOR COLLECTOR: Those which carry volumes between five thousand (5,000) and fifteen
thousand (15,000) vehicles per day and act as main feeders or connector streets between minor
collectors, serving as major traffic ways for heavy traffic flow between the various residential districts and
surrounding areas within the village.
STREET, MARGINAL: A street running parallel to and adjacent to or in the immediate vicinity of a major
street or highway and which has as its purpose the relief of such major street or highway from the local
service of abutting properties.
STREET, MINOR ARTERIAL: A street for interurban continuity, or regional importance that provides
reasonably continuous routes through the whole or major portion of the village, or any street which
carries volumes greater than fifteen thousand (15,000) vehicles.
STREET, MINOR COLLECTOR: Those carrying two thousand (2,000) to five thousand (5,000) vehicles
per day from local streets within residential development areas, to major collector or minor arterial.
SUBDIVISION: The division of any tract or parcel of land into two (2) or more lots or other divisions of
land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or for building development,
or if a new street is involved, any division of such parcel. This term includes resubdivision and, where
appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided. Application
for permit to construct two (2) or more dwellings on a parcel or tract of land or to construct one or more
additional dwellings on a parcel or tract of land where one or more dwellings already exist shall be
considered as a building development envisioning future transfer of ownership and shall be regarded as
a subdivision. For purposes of administration of these regulations, a parcel or tract of land shall be
deemed to have the boundaries and dimensions given in the current maps of record of the county of Will.
VILLAGE: The village of Mokena and its area of jurisdiction.
VILLAGE BOARD: The president and board of trustees of the village of Mokena.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 609/714
VILLAGE ENGINEER: The individual or firm appointed or contracted by the village who is licensed to
practice professional engineering in the state of Illinois and is responsible for reviewing subdivision plans
on behalf of the village, or his designated representative. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-1-6: APPROVALS, INTERPRETATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS:
A. After the adoption of these regulations, no land shall be subdivided and filed for record, nor any street
laid out, nor any improvements made to the land, until the plan or plans of the subdivision, streets or
improvements shall have been reviewed by the planning commission and approved by the village
board.
B. No lot, tract or parcel of land within any such subdivision shall be offered for sale nor shall any sale,
contract for sale, or option be made or given until such subdivision has been formally approved by the
village board.
C. No improvements, such as sidewalks, water supply, storm water drainage, sewerage facilities, street
lighting or grading, paving or surfacing of streets shall hereafter be made within any such subdivision
by any owner or his agents until the plans for the subdivision and the plans for improvements thereto
have been formally reviewed by the planning commission and approved by the village board.
D. Subdivisions of land lying outside the village and within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the village
limits presented for approval in accordance with the Illinois municipal code shall also conform to the
requirements of this title. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-1-7: INCORPORATION IN VILLAGE PLAN:
This title is hereby incorporated as a part of the official village plan. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-1-8: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this title is for any reason held invalid or
unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct
and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof.
(Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-1-9: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this title shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and a separate violation shall be deemed committed on each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)

Chapter 2
PLATTING PROCEDURES AND REQUIREMENTS
10-2-1: CONCEPT PLAN:
A. Filing Of Concept Plan: Twenty (20) paper and two (2) CADD file copies of a concept plan of a
proposed subdivision shall be submitted to the development director, along with the general
information application and other related forms as set out in the guide to community development,
who shall in turn transmit the necessary copies to the village board, village staff, consultants, and the
concept review team.
B. Contents: The concept plan shall contain the following: land uses, location of existing utilities, road
systems, densities, location of wetlands, floodplains and other general characteristics of a proposed
development.
C. Review Guidelines: The following guidelines shall govern review of the concept plan:
1. The review of a concept plan by the village board, or its designated concept review team, is strictly
tentative, involving merely the general acceptability of the layout as submitted.
2. The village board, or its designated concept review team, may introduce such changes or revisions
as are deemed necessary in the interests and needs of the community. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-2: PRELIMINARY PLAT:
A. Filing Of Preliminary Plat:
1. After review of the concept plan by the village board, or its designated concept review team, twenty
(20) paper and two (2) CADD file copies of a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision shall be
submitted to the development director, who shall in turn transmit the necessary copies to the village
planning commission, village board, village staff and consultants.
2. These copies shall be filed with the development director at least thirty (30) days prior to the
regular meeting of the planning commission at which action thereon shall be taken.
B. Contents: The preliminary plat shall contain the following:
1. Identification And Description:
a. Proposed name of the subdivision.
b. Location by township, section, town and range, or by other legal description.
c. Names and addresses, and telephone numbers of developer and designer who made the plat.
d. Scale of plat.
e. Date.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 611/714
f. North arrow.
2. Delineation Of Existing Conditions:
a. Boundary line of proposed subdivision indicated by solid heavy line and the total approximate
acreage encompassed thereby.
b. Location, widths and names of all existing or prior platted streets or other public ways, railroad
and utility rights of way, floodplains, floodways, wetlands, historically and/or archaeologically
sensitive areas, parks and other public open spaces, permanent buildings and structures, houses
or permanent easements and section and corporation lines, within or adjacent to the tract.
c. Exact location of existing sewers, water mains, culverts, storm water detention facilities, overland
release routes, streetlights, and other underground facilities within the tract indicating pipe sizes,
grades, and manholes.
d. Boundary lines of adjacent tracts of unsubdivided or subdivided land, showing owners, where
possible.
e. Existing zoning of proposed subdivision and adjacent tracts in zoned areas.
f. Contours at two foot (2') intervals, except where contour demands one foot (1') intervals. Bench
mark(s) upon which the contours are based. All elevations shall be referenced to USGS datum
and bench marks shall be noted.
3. Delineation Of Proposed Conditions:
a. Layout of streets and widths, and also the widths of crosswalks and easements. Typical street
cross sections including pavement thickness and type.
b. Layout, numbers and dimensions of lots.
c. Parcels of land intended to be dedicated or temporarily reserved for public use or set aside for
use of property owners in the subdivision.
d. Building setback lines, showing dimensions.
e. Layout and size of sewers, water mains, culverts, underground facilities within the tract,
floodplains, floodways, historically and/or archaeologically sensitive areas, wetlands, parks and
other public open spaces, storm water detention facilities, overland release routes, streetlights
and all other public improvements.
C. Approval Guidelines: The following guidelines shall govern approval of the preliminary plat:
1. The approval of a preliminary plat by the planning commission is strictly tentative, involving merely
the general acceptability of the layout as submitted.
2. The planning commission may introduce such changes or revisions as are deemed necessary in
the interests and needs of the community, and shall submit its report with the preliminary plat to the
village board for approval.
3. Subsequent approval will be required of the engineering proposals pertaining to water supply,
storm drainage, sewerage and sewage disposal, water mains, lighting, hydrants, grading, including
final lot and foundation elevation, paving, gradients and roadway widths, landscaping, erosion,
sedimentation control, and the surfacing of streets prior to the approval of the preliminary plat by
the village board.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 612/714
4. Evidence should be submitted that the local utilities can satisfactorily serve the area by the utility
easements shown.
D. Effective Period: Tentative approval shall be effective for a maximum period of twelve (12) months
unless, upon application of the developer, the village board grants an extension of up to an additional
six (6) months. If the final plat has not been recorded within this time limit, the preliminary plat must
again be submitted for approval. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-3: FINAL PLAT AND DEVELOPMENT PLANS:
A. Filing Of Final Plat:
1. After review of the preliminary plat by the planning commission and approval by village board, and
the fulfillment of the requirements of these regulations, twenty (20) paper, two (2) Mylar and two (2)
CADD file copies of a final plat of the proposed subdivision and five (5) complete sets of
development plans and engineering calculations shall be submitted to the development director,
who shall in turn transmit the necessary copies to the village planning commission, village board,
village staff and consultants. One tracing of the final plat of the subdivision, on Mylar, not to exceed
thirty six inches by forty eight inches (36" x 48") in size and five (5) complete sets of engineering
drawings and plans, shall be submitted to the planning commission for its recommendations to the
village board.
2. Upon review and recommendations by the planning commission, the developer shall submit the
final plat to the village board for its approval and signatures before filing with the county recorder. If
not recorded with the county recorder within three (3) months following approval by the village
board, the approval of the village board shall be null and void unless, upon application of the
developer, the planning commission grants an extension of up to an additional three (3) months.
3. Upon recording the final plat, the developer or owner shall submit, within thirty (30) calendar days,
three (3) copies of the recorded plat to the village clerk.
B. Contents: The final plat shall contain the following:
1. Identification And Description:
a. Name of subdivision.
b. Location by township, section, town and range, or by other legal description including the
statement that "all lying within the corporate limits of the Village of Mokena".
c. Names, addresses and telephone numbers of owners and certifications by a licensed surveyor.
d. Scale of one hundred feet to the inch (1" = 100') shown graphically.
e. Date.
f. North arrow.
2. Delineation:
a. Boundary of plat, based on an accurate traverse, with angular and lineal dimensions including
the acreage of the subdivision.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 613/714
b. Exact locations, width and name of all streets within and adjoining the plat, the exact location and
widths of all crosswalkways and the exact location, width and names of easements within and
adjoining the plat. Proposed street names shall be checked with the proper village officials.
c. True angles and distances to the nearest established street lines or official monuments which
shall be accurately described in the plat.
d. Municipal, township, county or section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by
distances and angles.
e. Radii, internal angles, points of curvatures, tangent bearings and lengths of all arcs.
f. All easements for rights of way provided for public services or utilities.
g. Easement provision contained herein for village and village franchised utilities that shall read as
follows:
An easement for serving the subdivision, and other property with storm drainage, sanitary
sewer, street lighting, potable water service and other public utilities, is hereby reserved and
granted to the Village of Mokena and its respective successors and assigns, jointly and
separately, to install, operate, maintain and remove, from time to time, facilities and equipment
used in the connection with the public water supply, transmission lines, sanitary sewers, storm
drainage system, street lighting system, or other public utility service, and their appurtenances,
either on, over, across, below or through the ground shown within the dotted lines on the plat
marked "Public Utility and/or Drainage Easement" and the property designated on the plat for
streets and alleys, together with the right to cut, trim or remove trees, bushes and roots as may
be reasonably required incident to the rights herein given, and the right to enter upon subdivided
property for all such purposes. Obstructions shall not be placed over grantees facilities or in,
upon or over, the property which will interfere with its proposed use within the dotted lines
marked "Public Utility and/or Drainage Easement" without the prior written consent of the
Grantees. After the installation of any such facilities, the grade of the subdivided property shall
not be altered in a manner so as to interfere with the proper operation and maintenance thereof.
h. All lot numbers and lines and bearings of lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths.
i. Accurate location of all monuments, which shall be concrete six inches by six inches by thirty
inches (6" x 6" x 30") with three-fourths inch (3/4") rebar cast in the center. Permanent stone or
concrete monuments shall be set at each corner or angle on the outside boundary of the
subdivision. Three-fourths inch (3/4") rebar shall be placed at all property corners. All U.S., state,
county or other official bench marks, monuments or triangular stations in or adjacent to the
property shall be preserved in precise position.
j. Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of all areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use,
with the purposes indicated thereon, and of any area to be reserved by deed covenant for
common uses of all property owners. Where the tract or tracts dedicated or reserved for future
village use are not within the corporate limits of the village, the certificate of dedication shall
provide that the future official act of annexation of such tract or tracts to the village shall
constitute a transfer of title to the village for such use.
k. Building setback lines.
l. Protective covenants which meet with the approval of the village board shall be made a part of
the final plat, and filed of record with the county recorder.
m. Certification by a registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him
and that the monuments and markers shown thereon exist as located and that all dimensional
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 614/714
and geodetic details are correct.
n. Notarized certification, by the owner or any mortgage holder of record, of the adoption of the plat
and the dedication of streets and other public areas.
o. Proper form for the approval of the village board and with space for signatures.
p. Approval by signature of the village board. This approval of the final plat shall not be deemed to
constitute or effect an acceptance by the public of the dedication of any street or other proposed
public way or space shown on the plat.
q. FEMA statement. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-4: CERTIFICATES REQUIRED:
The following certificates, or a form substantially similar thereto, shall appear on all such final plats and
said certificates shall be properly executed prior to the signing of such plat by the village authorities:
A. Form:
State of Illinois)
) ss
County of Will)
I, , do hereby certify that I have checked the legal description of the final plat, and find said plat to
be a true and correct representation of the subdivision as made by the surveyor.
Tax Mapping Official
Dated this day of , 19 .
B. Certificate By A Registered Professional Engineer: Certification by a registered professional engineer
and the owner of the property that shall read as follows:
I, , a registered professional engineer in Illinois and , the owner of the land depicted hereon, do
hereby state, that to the best of our knowledge and belief, reasonable provision has been made for
collection and diversion of surface waters and public areas, or drains which the subdivider has the
right to use, and that such surface waters will be planned for in accordance with generally accepted
engineering practices so as to reduce the likelihood of damage to the adjoining property because of
the construction of the subdivision. Further, as engineer, I hereby certify that the property which is the
subject of this subdivision or any part thereof is (is not) located within a special flood hazard area as
identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
The certificate shall be dated and have a line for the signature of the engineer and the owner.
C. Roadway Access Certificate: All plats involving subdivision of property with access from a state
highway or from a local highway which is not a village street shall have the following certificate affixed
thereto:
This plat has been approved by the Illinois Department of Transportation (or the relevant local
highway authority) with respect to roadway access. A plan that meets requirements contained in the
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 615/714
Illinois Department of Transportation's "Policy on Permits for Access Driveways to State Highways" or
the specifications of the relevant local highway authority, will be required.
The certificate shall be dated and have a line for the signature of the appropriate official of the
relevant state or local highway authority. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-5: GUARANTEE OF PERFORMANCE:
No approval of a final subdivision plat or planned unit development plan shall be made by the village
board unless the following supporting documents and fees have been submitted to the village:
A. Plans And Specifications: Ten (10) complete sets of plans and specifications and two (2) CADD file
copies of the plans thereof approved by the village engineer.
B. Engineer's Opinion Of Probable Construction Cost: An item by item breakdown by a licensed Illinois
registered professional engineer giving an opinion of probable construction cost of all improvements.
Such opinion shall be based on prevailing construction costs and shall be subject to the approval of
the village engineer.
C. Letters Of Credit: Two (2) letters of credit will be required for each subdivision or development.
1. The first letter of credit (LOC1) shall be for the following major items of work:
a. Storm water detention including restoration;
b. Underground utilities;
c. Streets up through binder course;
d. Erosion control facilities;
e. Street signs;
f. Streetlights.
LOC1 shall have a two (2) year time period. All LOC1 items of work must be completed no later
than two (2) years from the date the final plat is recorded.
2. The second letter of credit (LOC2) shall be for the following major items of work:
a. Surface course;
b. Sidewalks;
c. Parkway restoration;
d. Trees.
LOC2 shall have a four (4) year time period. All LOC2 items of work must be completed no later
than four (4) years from the date the final plat is recorded.
Both letters of credit shall be in a form provided by the village. Letters of credit shall be issued by
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 616/714
a financial institution with assets in excess of fifty million dollars ($50,000,000.00), in an amount
equal to one hundred ten percent (110%) of the approved engineer's opinion of probable
construction cost of all required public improvements securing the satisfactory completion of all
said improvements in accordance with the approved plans and specifications. Such letter of
credit shall be subject to the approval of the village engineer. A letter of credit shall also be
required for the construction or extension of any other public improvements, which are not
contemplated under this section as part of a subdivision or planned unit development.
D. Village Fees: Village contribution, inspection, legal, and consultant fees.
E. Recapture Fees: Recapture fees (where applicable).
F. Permits: Permits from utility companies and other government agencies. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-6: LETTER OF CREDIT REDUCTION AND RELEASE PROCEDURE:
Letters of credit may be reduced or released in the following manner:
A. LOC1 First Reduction:
1. The items of work which may be reduced in the first reduction in LOC1 include storm water
detention including restoration, underground utilities, and erosion control facilities. All items of work
must be completed before the first reduction will be made.
2. Two (2) months prior to the developer requesting the first reduction, record drawings shall be
submitted to the village engineer for review.
The record drawings shall consist of rim and invert elevations of all storm and sanitary structures;
slopes and sizes of all storm and sanitary mains; distance from nearest downstream manhole to
water, sanitary and storm services; station and offset to all storm and sanitary structures, valves
and fire hydrants; and elevations and dimensions of storm water detention facilities.
3. The first reduction may be made by the village board upon recommendation by the village
engineer.
4. The first reduction will reduce LOC1 from one hundred ten percent (110%) to not less than ten
percent (10%) for the items of work included in the first reduction. The ten percent (10%) will be
held for maintenance of the items of work included in the first reduction.
B. LOC1 Second Reduction:
1. The items of work which may be reduced in the second reduction in LOC1 include streets up
through the binder course, street signs, and streetlights. All items of work must be completed
before the second reduction will be made.
2. The second reduction may be made by the village board upon recommendation by the village
engineer.
3. The second reduction will reduce the LOC1 from one hundred ten percent (110%) to ten percent
(10%) for the items of work included in the second reduction. The ten percent (10%) will be held for
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 617/714
maintenance of the items of work included in the second reduction until the village accepts all
public improvements.
C. LOC2 Reduction:
1. The items of work which may be reduced in the reduction of LOC2 include surface course,
sidewalks, parkway restoration and trees. All items of work included in LOC2 must be completed
before the reduction will be made.
2. Three (3) months prior to the developer requesting the reduction, a request for a punch list for all
items of work shall be made to the village engineer.
3. The developer must complete the punch list prior to the reduction.
4. The reduction in the letter of credit may be made by the village board upon recommendation by the
village engineer.
5. The reduction will reduce LOC2 from one hundred ten percent (110%) to ten percent (10%) for the
items of work requested in the reduction. The ten percent (10%) will be held for maintenance of the
items of work included in both LOC1 and LOC2. LOC1 may be released at this time. A cash bond
may be accepted by the village in lieu of the ten percent (10%) remainder of LOC2.
6. The village will accept all public improvements and release LOC2 or cash bond twelve (12) months
after all public improvements are completed and approved. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-7: SURVEYS REQUIRED:
A. Preliminary Plat Of Survey: Two (2) copies of a preliminary plat of survey, dated not more than six (6)
months from the date of submission, shall be submitted with the application for principal structure
permit, containing the following information:
1. Legal description of the property.
2. Lot number, lot size and building setback line.
3. Location of existing utility, drainage or other easements.
4. North arrow and scale.
5. Bench mark, plainly labeled and within three hundred feet (300') of the proposed developed lot.
6. Location and size of the proposed building on the lot, with dimensions to the front, rear and side
property lines indicated.
7. Elevations for top of foundation.
8. Elevations at all four (4) property corners and any additional spot elevations required to indicate
overland drainage patterns.
9. Elevations for the top of existing foundations in the adjacent properties.
10. Proposed driveway and sidewalk placement, sanitary sewer and water main locations, and soil
erosion plan.
11. Stamp and signature of a registered land surveyor or a registered professional engineer.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 618/714
B. Top Of Foundation Survey: One copy of a spotted plat of survey shall be submitted to the building
inspector after the foundation walls have been completed and before further construction is
undertaken, containing:
1. Exact location of the structure in relation to the lot lines.
2. Elevation for top of foundation.
3. Stamp and signature of a registered land surveyor or a registered professional engineer, including
the following statement: "The top of foundation survey fully complies with the approved engineering
plans for the lot." In the event that the final grading of the lot differs from the approved plans, a
statement must be made as to the nature of the change. The village engineer may approve minor
changes discovered during this top of foundation survey preparation, providing that the changes do
not adversely affect the drainage on the land in question or other lands.
C. First Lot Grading Survey - Before Landscaping: Prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy for any
building and after installation of topsoil and prior to installation of landscaping, the builder shall be
required to submit two (2) blueprint copies of the plat for the existing lot to the development director
indicating the following:
1. Legal description.
2. Builder's name, unit number, lot number, and street address.
3. Existing top of foundation grade.
4. Existing garage floor elevation at front of home.
5. Indicate existing driveway slope measured along the center line of the driveway in percentage to
house side edge of sidewalk, or to curb flowline if there is no sidewalk.
6. Existing lot corner elevations, and drainage arrows.
7. Existing finished grade elevation at the four (4) corners of the home.
8. Existing elevation of all drainage break points within the lot.
9. Existing location and elevation of utility structures on the lot.
10. Location of measurements of any additional accessory or detached building.
11. All concrete, masonry or brick flatwork.
12. Stamp and signature of a registered land surveyor or a registered professional engineer, including
the following statement: "The final grading of the lot has been completed and fully complies with the
approved engineering plans for the lot." In the event that the final grading of the lot differs from the
approved plans, a statement must be made as to the nature of the change. The village engineer
may approve minor changes discovered during this final blueprint preparation, providing that the
changes do not adversely affect the drainage on the land in question or other lands.
D. Second Lot Grading Survey - After Landscaping: Prior to release of the landscape guarantee deposit
for any residential building, the homeowner shall be required to submit two (2) blueprint copies of the
plat for the existing lot to the development director, indicating the following:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 619/714
1. Legal description.
2. Owners name, unit number, lot number and street address.
3. Existing top of foundation grade.
4. Existing garage floor elevation at front of home.
5. Indicate existing driveway slope measure along the center line of the driveway in percentage to
house side edge of sidewalk, or to curb flowline if there is no sidewalk.
6. Existing lot corner elevations, and drainage arrows.
7. Existing finished grade elevation at the four (4) corners of the home.
8. Existing elevation of all drainage break points within the lot.
9. Existing location and elevation of utility structures on the lot.
10. Location and measurements of any additional accessory or detached building.
11. All concrete, masonry or brick flatwork.
12. Stamp and signature of a registered land surveyor or a registered professional engineer, including
the following statement: "The final grading of the lot has been completed and fully complies with the
approved engineering plans for the lot." In the event that the final grading of the lot differs from the
approved plans, a statement must be made as to the nature of the change. The village engineer
may approve minor changes discovered during this final blueprint preparation, providing that the
changes do not adversely affect the drainage on the land in question or other lands. (Ord. 1567, 1-
26-1998)
10-2-8: OCCUPANCY PERMIT:
A. No occupancy permit shall be granted for the use of any building or structure within a subdivision or lot
division approved under this title until storm water detention including restoration, underground
utilities, streets up to the binder course, street signs and streetlights are installed and operable.
B. In addition to any other fees payable at the time that a certificate of occupancy shall be issued, there
shall be deposited with the village, cash or adequate security in the amount of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) per lot which shall be known as the landscape guarantee deposit. The deposit shall be in
addition to any project performance bond or letter of credit previously established with regard to the
property. The purpose of this landscape guarantee deposit shall be to assure that the property owner
obtains the required landscape permit and completes all landscaping in accordance with the
approved grading plan.
The village shall return the amount of the deposit or release the amount of the security as soon as a
second lot grading survey meeting the requirements of subsection 10-2-7D of this chapter is
submitted to and approved by the development director in accordance with the landscape permit
required in section 10-2-9 of this chapter. The amount of the landscaping guarantee deposit shall be
held or remain available for the benefit of the village until approval by the village of the second lot
grading survey. The village shall notify the person depositing the landscape guarantee deposit of any
specific defect existing in the drainage of the lot. In the event that the defect is not corrected after
reasonable notice, the village may utilize the funds to correct the defect. Provided, however, that the
utilization of this grading guarantee deposit shall not prevent the village from taking other action
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 620/714
against the person responsible for the defect in drainage. Without regard to any other provision of this
title, the grading guarantee deposit shall not be released by the village until the entire area
immediately affected by the drainage characteristics of the individual lot shall have also been found to
comply with the ordinances of the village relating to drainage.
C. A variance from any part of the requirements for the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for singlefamily
lots may be granted by the development director in light of an inability of the builder to
complete such requirements due to inclement weather or upon other good cause shown. When a
variance is so issued, there shall be deposited with the village a cash payment equal to the cost of the
unfinished item(s) per lot which shall be known as the occupancy variance deposit. The purpose of
this occupancy variance deposit shall be to assure that the items not completed will be completed
within sixty (60) days after the weather, soil conditions or other impediment to completion allows for
the uncompleted work to be finished. The amount of the deposit shall be held by the village until the
work has been completed. In the event that the defect is not corrected within the sixty (60) day period
set forth above, the village may, after reasonable notice, utilize the funds to correct the defect.
Provided, however, that the utilization of this occupancy variance deposit shall not prevent the village
from taking other action against the person responsible for the defect preventing the issuance of the
certificate of occupancy, including, but not limited to, the filing of a lawsuit for injunction, ordinance
violation or the withdrawal of the occupancy permit. Without regard to any provision contained within
this title, the occupancy variance deposit shall not be released by the village until the entire area
immediately affected by the uncompleted items of the individual lot shall have also been found to
comply with the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-9: LANDSCAPE PERMIT REQUIREMENT:
A. Landscaping Application: Prior to the landscaping of any new building, the property owner(s) must
submit a detailed application showing, among other things:
1. First lot grading survey;
2. Location, type and size of any and all trees, shrubs, fencing, other landscaping amenities, grass
areas and location of berms, drainage easements and swales, if applicable;
3. Location of underground sprinklers, if any. (Additional permit required for sprinkling systems);
4. Location of drain tiles, down spouts and sump pump discharge.
B. Landscaping Permit: The village will issue a landscaping permit to the property owner upon
completion of the following:
1. Submittal of landscaping application in conformance with village ordinances and regulations;
2. Payment to the village of a permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00);
3. Receipt and approval of the first lot grading survey;
4. A security deposit in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to ensure all landscaping will be
completed within six (6) months of the date of the issuance of the landscaping permit. If a one
thousand dollar ($1,000.00) landscape guarantee deposit has been previously submitted to the
village by the applicant, this deposit may replace, and serve the function of, the security deposit for
the landscape permit.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 621/714
C. Time To Complete Landscaping: All landscaping must be completed within six (6) months of the date
of the issuance of the permit. The development director is authorized to extend the permit date for
thirty (30) days due to adverse weather conditions.
D. Failure To Timely Complete Landscaping: If all landscaping is not completed within the allowed time,
the one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) landscape guarantee/security deposit is forfeited by the property
owner to the village. Forfeiture of the landscape guarantee deposit shall not constitute a waiver of any
other legal rights or remedies available to the village as set forth herein or that may be available at
law or in equity.
E. Deposit Refund/Certification: If the landscaping is timely completed, the village will return the one
thousand dollar ($1,000.00) landscape guarantee/security deposit to the property owner, without
interest. At the time of request for and prior to any refund, the property owner(s) shall submit to the
village for approval the second lot grading survey by a registered land surveyor or a registered
professional engineer. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-10: NONRESIDENTIAL LANDSCAPE; GUARANTEE DEPOSIT:
No building permit shall be issued for new construction in a nonresidential zoning district, which requires
the installation of landscaping, until a landscape guarantee deposit is first submitted to the village by the
permit applicant. The landscape guarantee deposit shall be in the form of a certified check in an amount
equal to the cost estimate for the landscape plan approved by the village. The landscape cost estimate
shall include costs of plant materials, sod, retaining walls, labor and any other related costs as
determined by the village. The landscape guarantee deposit shall be returned to the permit applicant
upon completion of all items on the approved landscape plan. Provided, however, that the utilization of
this landscape guarantee deposit shall not prevent the village from taking other action against the person
responsible for the defect preventing the issuance of the certificate of occupancy, including, but not
limited to, the filing of a lawsuit for injunction, ordinance violation or the withdrawal of the permit. Without
regard to any provision contained within this title, the landscape guarantee deposit shall not be released
by the village until the entire area immediately affected by the uncompleted items of the individual lot
shall have also been found to comply with the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-11: VARIATIONS:
The planning commission may recommend variations from the requirements of this title in specific cases
which, in its opinion, do not adversely affect the comprehensive plan or intent of this title. Such
recommendations shall be communicated to the village board or governing county authorities in writing
substantiating the recommended variation. The village board of trustees may approve variations from the
requirements of this title when, in its opinion, such variations will not adversely affect the comprehensive
plan or the intent of this title. The village board may only grant such variations by ordinance which shall
state the special reasons which require a variation from this title. The village board shall not approve
variations that result in requirements less than required by the Will County subdivision regulations
ordinance for subdivisions located in the unincorporated areas under the extraterritorial jurisdiction of this
title. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-12: ENFORCEMENT:
No plat of subdivision shall be recorded in the county recorder's office or have any validity until it shall
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 622/714
have been approved in the manner prescribed in this title. The village board, by ordinance, shall appoint
the enforcing officer of this title, whose duty shall be to enforce the provisions hereof. The enforcing
officer may call upon any department or official of the village to furnish him with such information and
assistance as may be deemed necessary for this purpose, and it shall be the duty of such department or
officer to furnish such information and assistance whenever required. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-13: RECORD OF PLATS:
All such plats of subdivision, after the same have been submitted and approved as provided in this title,
shall be filed and kept by the village among the records of the village. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-14: SALE OR LEASE OF LOT, FINAL PLAT APPROVAL:
No one shall sell or offer for sale, lease or offer for lease, while this title is in effect any lot or, within the
incorporated limits of the village, any resubdivision of any block therein or within contiguous territory and
not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the incorporated boundary of the village, before a
final plat of subdivision has been approved by the planning commission and the village board as required
by this title. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-2-15: PLANNED DEVELOPMENT REVIEW AND INSPECTION FEES:
The village shall charge fees to developers for planned development review and inspection services on
the basis of a fixed fee schedule as set forth below. Such fees shall be paid by certified check, money
order or United States currency to the village treasurer, and the plans and plat for any proposed
development or subdivision, preliminary and otherwise, shall not be considered without the receipt paid
from the village treasurer being first exhibited. Said fee shall not be refunded, regardless of whether the
proposed development is approved or disapproved.
A. Administrative Fees:

5.01 to 40 acres $50.00 per acre
Greater than 40.1 acres $2,000.00 + $20.00 per acre over 40.01 acres
The above fees shall be paid as follows:
50 percent upon submittal of conceptual plan
50 percent upon submittal of preliminary plan

The above fees shall be paid upon submittal of conceptual plan, but shall be credited toward
engineering review fees upon submittal of preliminary plan, after such fees shall have been
determined in accordance with subsection C of this section.
C. Engineering Review Fees:
1. All single phased planned development plans which contemplate or which may otherwise require
the construction and/or dedication of public improvements, shall be submitted to the village for
review by the village engineer. The fee for such review shall be determined based upon the amount
of the letter of credit, as required for the proposed public improvements, in accordance with the
following fee table:
Letter Of Credit Amount Fee
$10,000.00 or less $275.00 minimum
$10,000.01 to $20,000.00 $275.00 plus 3.5 percent of amount over $10,000.00
$20,000.01 to $50,000.00 $575.00 plus 3.0 percent of amount over $20,000.00
$50,000.01 to $100,000.00 $1,325.00 plus 2.75 percent of amount over $50,000.00
$100,000.01 to $500,000.00 $2,450.00 plus 2.5 percent of amount over $100,000.00
$500,000.01 and over $10,450.00 plus 1.5 percent of amount over $500,000.00
The above engineering review fees shall be paid upon submittal of the preliminary plan. Should the
actual letter of credit amount not be available at the time of submittal of the preliminary plan, the
developer shall submit as a substitute therefor an engineer's opinion of probable construction cost
for the proposed public improvements. Upon approval by the village engineer, such estimate shall
be utilized as the basis for calculating the review fees. Such fees shall be adjusted in accordance
with the letter of credit amount when finally determined. Should additional fees be required, they
shall be paid prior to final plan approval. If the final letter of credit amount is less than the initial
estimate as submitted by the developer, the initial estimate shall be utilized unless the difference
between the initial estimate and the final letter of credit amount is greater than twenty five percent
(25%), in which case the village shall refund that amount of the difference in excess of twenty five
percent (25%).

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 624/714
2. For multiphased planned development plans which contemplate or which may otherwise require
the construction and/or dedication of public improvements and which would require phased
engineering review of final plan submittals, the engineering review fees shall be paid as follows:

the entire development, as required for the proposed public improvements, in accordance with
the fee table set forth in subsection C1 of this section, shall be paid upon submittal of the
preliminary plan.
b. As each phase is submitted for final plan approval, that percentage of the figure as determined
based upon the letter of credit amount for the entire development, in accordance with the fee
table set forth in subsection C1 of this section to which the value of the submitted phase
corresponds, shall be paid prior to final plan approval for that phase.

$17,950.00

the review fees. Such fees shall be adjusted in accordance with the letter of credit amount when
finally determined. Should additional fees be required, they shall be apportioned equally to any
remaining payments contemplated under the payment schedule set forth in subsection C2b of
this section. If the final letter of credit amount is less than the initial estimate as submitted by the
developer, the initial estimate shall be utilized unless the difference between the initial estimate
and the final letter of credit amount is greater than twenty five percent (25%), in which case the
village shall refund that amount of the difference in excess of twenty five percent (25%).

services shall be determined based upon the amount of the letters of credit as required for the
proposed public improvements in accordance with the following fee table:

2. Engineering review fees shall be charged at the hourly rate specified for work of this type in the
consultant engineering contract between the village and the village engineer which is in effect at the
time such fees are charged or at a rate as established by the village if review is conducted by
authorized village personnel. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
Chapter 3
DESIGN STANDARDS
10-3-1: STREET PLAN:
The subdivision of land or the dedication of land for public streets, highways, alleys or other public use,
shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public
convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by
such streets. The arrangement of streets in a subdivision should:
A. Provide for continuation of existing streets in surrounding areas by connecting to existing streets and
extending proposed streets to the limits of the subdivision for future extension.
B. Conform to a transportation and/or comprehensive plan adopted by the planning commission and
village board.
C. Provide for a minimum of two (2) points of ingress and egress. (Ord. 1567, 1-26-1998)
10-3-2: MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR STREETS:
A. General: All streets shall be designed in accordance with the "Illinois Department Of Transportation's
Bureau Of Local Roads And Streets Administrative Policies", the American Association of State
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=1090 626/714
Highway and Transportation Officials, "A Policy On The Geometric Design Of Highways And Streets",
and the "Village Of Mokena Standard Specifications For Subdivision Improvements", latest editions.
B. Pavement Design: All pavement shall be designed in accordance with previously referenced
standards and manuals. The design thickness shall be dependent on the soil support value and the
projected traffic factor. However, in no case shall the pavement design be less than that indicated in
the "Village Of Mokena Standard Specifications For Subdivision Improvements".
A pavement design shall be submitted for each subdivision which consists of:
1. A soil analysis (minimum IBR = 3 or Eri = 3 ksi);
2. Staged construction - construction traffic on binder course and aggregate base course or
aggregate subbase, bituminous base course and binder course, and twenty (20) year life for
completed pavement with remaining life of existing pavement considered;
3. Trip generation and projections based on Institute of Transportation Engineer's procedures or other
methods accepted by the village; and
4. Illinois department of transportation's bureau of local roads and streets administrative policies
procedures.
C. Geometric Design:

D. Street Grades: Streets shall be related appropriately to the topography and all streets shall be
arranged so as to obtain building sites above the grades of the streets. Grades of streets shall
conform as closely as possible to the original topography. A combination of steep grade curves shall
be avoided.
E. Local Streets: Local streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged.
F. Intersections And Confluences: All street intersections and confluences shall encourage safe traffic
flow.
G. Cul-De-Sac: The maximum length of cul-de-sacs shall be five hundred feet (500') measured along the
centerline of the road from the center of circle to the near right of way of the intersecting street.
H. Highway Entrances: If the tract of land proposed to be subdivided or any part thereof lies adjacent to a
highway over which the department of transportation of the state or county has jurisdiction with
respect to maintenance and upkeep thereof, and an entrance or entrances are desired from such
highway to lots, streets, roadways or alleys in such proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall submit
to the planning commission of the village an approved permit from the proper authorities. All
improvements shall be done in accordance with the requirements of that agency.
